Disposition: - REPORT NARRATIVE SYNOPSIS: On 02/24/2024, Incarcerated Person (IP) Maradiaga, Jose (BN 24707521) assaulted and resisted a lawful order given to him by Deputy Valenzuela 0641 while inside the elevator of the San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ). Deputies had to use force to bring him under control. IP Maradiaga was medically assessed by Nurse (GG x. Deputy Valenzuela was sent to Concentra Urgent Care for soreness to the face region, soreness to the right pinky finger, and abrasion on both knees and his upper left shoulder area sustained during the use of force. CCTV footage, photos, and Body Worn Camera (BWC) footage are available. Deputy Valenzuela does desire prosecution for 69 PC (A) Obstruct/ Resist Executive Officer with Serious Injury and 243 PC (C)(2) Battery On a Peace Or Police Officer. ORIGIN: On 02/24/24, was assigned to work the 2nd Floor Search Medical Screening Deputy position at the San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ). At approximately 1545 hours, heard traffic over the radio there was an active use of force involving a deputy and an IP inside the elevator on the 2nd Floor. immediately ran to the elevator well to assist. Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By $SH4534 - WELDON, JOHN San Diego Central Jail $H3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 2/24/2024 5:17:39 PM $H0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 02/27/2024 14:08:24 NetRMS_CASDCRrtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:13 PM San Diego County Sheriffs Department Arrest/Juvenile Contact Report 4 Page 4 of 7 Case No. 24107659 CAD Event No.: E9081221 Case Disposition: Arrest Primary Victim: VALENZUELA, Deputy Report No. 24107659.1 Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH4534 - WELDON, JOHN San Diego Central Jail SH3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 2/24/2024 5:17:39 PM SH0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 02/27/2024 14:08:24 NetRMS_CASDCR.rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:13 PM BACKGROUND: Maradiaga, Jose (BN 24707521) is currently in custody for INVESTIGATION: Upon arrival to the 2nd Floor elevator well, I observed Deputy Valenzuela, Deputy Ordonez 2545, Deputy McAnany 4060, and Corporal Uson 3452 physically struggling with an incarcerated person later identified as Maradiaga, Jose (BN24707521) on the floor of Elevator 3. It appeared each deputy was trying to gain control of Maradiaga as he physically thrashing his body around causing the deputies to use controlling force. I was later informed that Deputy Valenzuela had to utilize closed fist strikes to gain compliance as well as in self defense. For more information, please reference Deputy Valenzuela, Deputy Ordonez, Corporal Uson, and Deputy McAnanys Officer Reports. As I arrived and assessed where I could assist, Corporal Wanzer also arrived on scene and instructed the deputies involved to remove Maradiaga from the elevator. In response, I grabbed Maradiagas right arm with both of my hands and, with a pulling motion, pulled Maradiaga out of the elevator with the assistance of the other involved deputies. Once out of Elevator 3 and in the incarcerated person well on his stomach, Maradiaga continued to resist by thrashing about and tensing his body. While maintaining grip on Maradiagas right arm, Corporal Wanzer took control of Maradiagas right arm, allowing me to apply downward pressure on Maradiagas upper back region to suppress his efforts of thrashing about. Corporal Wanzer then guided Maradiagas right hand towards me, allowing me to place both of his hands in handcuffs because Maradiagas left hand was now also behind his back. With Maradiaga now in handcuffs, another deputy was able to secure Maradiaga in leg chains. Had I not used force, we would not have been able to place Maradiaga in restraints. Once Maradiaga was placed into handcuffs and leg chains, deputies lifted him onto the gurney, and was secured to the gurney via the affixed gurney straps. Maradiaga was then escorted to the 2nd Floor Strip Search room and medically evaluated by Nurse . Nurse treated Maradiagas injuries and cleared him to be housed. Deputy Getnet 4549 took photos of all visible injuries that Maradiaga sustained. Sgt. Applebaum 3075 took photos of Deputy Valenzuelas visible injuries before Deputy Valenzuela went to the hospital for treatment. Deputy Crist 3604 from Classification arrived on scene shortly after and interviewed Maradiaga and determined he would be housed on the 5th Floor with a classification code of level 5. Deputy Crist also informed me that Maradiaga would now be dressed in Dayglow Green Clothing to indicate his assaultive status. (b)(6)(C) (b)(6)(C) (b)(6)(C) (b)(6)(C) San Diego County Sheriffs Department Arrest/Juvenile Contact Report 5 Page 5 of 7 Case No. 24107659 CAD Event No.: E9081221 Case Disposition: Arrest Primary Victim: VALENZUELA, Deputy Report No. 24107659.1 Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH4534 - WELDON, JOHN San Diego Central Jail SH3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 2/24/2024 5:17:39 PM SH0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 02/27/2024 14:08:24 NetRMS_CASDCR.rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:13 PM Once Maradiaga was done being medically and mentally assessed, he was removed from the gurney. Due to the previous use of force and assaultive behavior, Maradiaga remained in leg chains and handcuffs as I utilized sheers to remove his clothing. Maradiaga was placed into Dayglow Green Jail Clothing as an indication of his assaultive behavior. Maradiaga was then secured back onto the gurney and escorted to the 5th Floor. Once on the 5th Floor, Maradiaga was removed from the gurney and placed on the floor of 5D . Corporal Wanzer, Deputy McAnany, Deputy Ordonez, Deputy Delgado, and I entered the cell with Maradiaga to safely remove his restraints. As I removed the handcuffs from Maradiagas left wrist, Corporal Wanzer attempted to guide Maradiagas left hand under his stomach and ordered him not to move. Deputy Delgado then entered the cell to articulate the orders in Spanish to help Maradiaga understand the orders better. However, despite the instructions given to Maradiaga, he disobeyed the order and attempted to free his hand from under his stomach. To suppress Maradiagas efforts of resistance, I applied downward pressure with both hands to Maradiagas upper back region. My force was effective as Corporal Wanzer was able to secure Maradiagas left hand under his stomach. Maradiagas handcuffs and leg chains were removed, and all parties safely exited the cell without further incident. Had I not pushed Maradiagas upper back, we would not have been able to exit the cell safely. In total, Maradiaga was on the gurney for approximately 30 minutes. Sgt. Cardoza 3223 was the designated safety officer for the duration of the gurney escort. On 02/25/2024, I went to the 5th Floor and had Deputy Delgado 0186 translate and read Maradiagas Miranda Rights verbatim from a deputy-issued notebook. Maradiaga responded yes to question number one and yes to question number two. Deputy Delgado asked Maradiaga what happened in the elevator, and he essentially said the following. STATEMENTS: (Statement of Maradiaga, Jose) When asked what happened, Maradiaga essentially said he was arguing with the Deputy and that he was attacked and didnt do anything wrong. Deputy Delgado asked him if he had anything relevant to the situation he wanted to tell me, but Maradiaga said no. Based on Maradiaga having no other statements to add, I ended my conversation with Maradiaga. INVESTIGATION CONTINUED: On 2/25/2024, I was informed that Deputy Valenzuela sustained abrasions to both knees, redness to his face, swelling on his right pinky finger, and a scratch to his left shoulder region. I also called the 3rd Floor Clinics area. I was informed by Nurse Practitioner that Maradiaga sustained a deviated nasal septum and bruising to his left eye and went to the hospital for treatment. Maradiaga returned from the hospital and was placed back in 5D . Based on the above information, Maradiaga will be charged with (b)(6)(A (b)(6)(C) (b)(6)(A San Diego County Sheriffs Department Arrest/Juvenile Contact Report 6 Page 6 of 7 Case No. 24107659 CAD Event No.: E9081221 Case Disposition: Arrest Primary Victim: VALENZUELA, Deputy Report No. 24107659.1 Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH4534 - WELDON, JOHN San Diego Central Jail SH3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 2/24/2024 5:17:39 PM SH0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 02/27/2024 14:08:24 NetRMS_CASDCR.rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:13 PM PC 69 (A) Obstruct/ Resist Executive Officer With Serious Injury and PC 243 (C)(2) Battery On a Peace Or Police Officer. EVIDENCE: Relevant body-worn camera footage, CCTV footage, and photos will be uploaded and attached to this case. I transferred the CCTV and photos onto a CD and secured it in a manila envelope. The evidence CD was then secured into SDCJ Evidence Locker 33. Item: 1 Description: 1 CD containing photos of IP Maradiaga and Deputy Valenzuela, CCTV, and BWC footage. Maradiaga was placed into Dayglow Green Jail Clothing as an indication of his assaultive behavior. Maradiaga was then secured back onto the gurney and escorted to the 5th Floor. Once on the 5th Floor, Maradiaga was removed from the gurney and placed on the floor of 5D . Corporal Wanzer, Deputy McAnany, Deputy Ordonez, Deputy Delgado, and I entered the cell with Maradiaga to safely remove his restraints. As I removed the handcuffs from Maradiagas left wrist, Corporal Wanzer attempted to guide Maradiagas left hand under his stomach and ordered him not to move. Deputy Delgado then entered the cell to articulate the orders in Spanish to help Maradiaga understand the orders better. However, despite the instructions given to Maradiaga, he disobeyed the order and attempted to free his hand from under his stomach. To suppress Maradiagas efforts of resistance, I applied downward pressure with both hands to Maradiagas upper back region. My force was effective as Corporal Wanzer was able to secure Maradiagas left hand under his stomach. Maradiagas handcuffs and leg chains were removed, and all parties safely exited the cell without further incident. Had I not pushed Maradiagas upper back, we would not have been able to exit the cell safely. In total, Maradiaga was on the gurney for approximately 30 minutes. Sgt. Cardoza 3223 was the designated safety officer for the duration of the gurney escort. On 02/25/2024, I went to the 5th Floor and had Deputy Delgado 0186 translate and read Maradiagas Miranda Rights verbatim from a deputy-issued notebook. Maradiaga responded yes to question number one and yes to question number two. Deputy Delgado asked Maradiaga what happened in the elevator, and he essentially said the following. STATEMENTS: (Statement of Maradiaga, Jose) When asked what happened, Maradiaga essentially said he was arguing with the Deputy and that he was attacked and didnt do anything wrong. Deputy Delgado asked him if he had anything relevant to the situation he wanted to tell me, but Maradiaga said no. Based on Maradiaga having no other statements to add, I ended my conversation with Maradiaga. Maradiaga told me he remembered the incident. asked him to tell me what happened. Maradiaga told me he remembered being taken to another location. asked him if he did not want to be taken to another location. Maradiaga told me he did not know where he was being taken and asked where he was going. asked Maradiaga if that was the reason why he resisted while being escorted in the elevator. Maradiaga told me that was not the reason, and he did nothing. asked Maradiaga if he could tell why he was taken to the floor while in the elevator. He told me he did not hit anyone and that he was the one who was hit in the face. asked what he did because he was hit. Maradiaga told me he did not do anything. I asked Maradiaga if he fought back or if he defended himself. Maradiaga told me he did not. He repeated he was taken, got his shirt cut off, and then taken away. I asked Maradiaga if he had fought back. He told me he did not because he respects the police. I asked him again if, while in the elevator, he turned toward the deputy. Maradiaga told me he was facing the wall when he was grabbed and hit. I asked him to tell me how he reacted to that. Maradiaga said he did nothing and only asked why he was being grabbed. Maradiaga said he did not do anything and did not hit the deputy. I asked Maradiaga if he had any questions for me. He told me he did not and that everything was okay. Country: County Residence: Undocumented: pemeeeeeeas EE RResigent Race: Date of Birth / Age: Height Weight: Facial Hair- Complexion: tw e ee fo ee CONTACT INFORMATION IDENTIFICATION: BN. om BN - Booking Number 24707521 Type: State: Country: SIM JIMS Number cae a ire: Injury: Extent Of Treatment: Violent Cnme Circumstances: blue collared shirt and tan pants 2 - Treated at Scene Subject injury Description: None Officer Injury Descnption: None Case 24107659 Call for Service E9081221 ORIGIN: On 2/24/2024, at about 1545 hours, was assigned to work the Search Deputy position at the San Diego Central Jail (SDC4J). At about 1555 Hours, heard a call on the facility radio that indicated a fight might be occurring in the elevator well on the 2nd Floor. DEPUTYS OBSERVATIONS AND ACTIONS: entered the elevator well and observed other deputies struggling to control a person inside the open elevator, later identified as Maradiaga, Jose 24707521. noticed that Maradiagas right arm was uncontrolled and tucked under his body so that deputies could not control it. was concerned that he might strike or grab other deputies with the hand as they attempted to control him. grabbed his right wrist with both of my hands and pulled it away from his body. then pushed it towards the small of his back so that he could be handcuffed. My initial force was ineffective, and he continued to struggle with his hands unsecured in handcuffs. Cpl. Wanzer 3363 suggested that Maradiaga be moved from the confines of the elevator towards the 2nd Floor elevator well so that additional deputies could assist in controlling him. He was pulled out of the elevator by other deputies. let go of his right wrist when Cpl. Wanzer took control of the wrist. Maradiaga was prone on the elevator well floor at this time. noticed that other deputies were controlling Maradiagas hands/wrists, but he was not handcuffed because he was resisting. He was tense, and was concerned he would attempt to stand up. used both hands to push down on his head to ensure he did not stand up. maintained the downward pressure on his head until both of his hands were secured in handcuffs, and his feet were both secured in a leg chain. Had not used force, we would not have been able to control Maradiaga and placed him in restraints. DEPUTYS OBSERVATIONS AND ACTIONS: While releasing IPs on the 2nd Floor, heard over the radio that there was a use of force on elevator three on the 2nd Floor. responded toward elevator three and observed IP Maradiaga, Jose BN24707521, inside the elevator and on the floor, actively resisting deputies by tensing his hands and legs and attempting to strike them. Additionally, he was refusing to give them his hands for handcuffing. The deputies were Deputy Weldon 4534, Deputy Ordonez 2545, Deputy McAnany 4060, and Corporal Uson 3452. As entered the elevator, observed that IP Maradiagas legs were kicking toward deputies, trying to control him. controlled his legs by initially grabbing them with both hands, then helped move IP Maradiaga outside the elevator by picking him up from his legs with the other deputies and putting him outside the elevator. Once outside the elevator, used both hands to cross his legs and apply downward pressure. did this to prevent him from being able to kick at us and control his legs. If had not used downward pressure, he would have had the ability to cause injury to one of us. applied downward pressure for approximately 60 seconds. was then handed leg restraints by Deputy Delgado 0186. The safety officer was Sergeant Cardoza 3223. IP Maradiaga was transported from the IP elevator well on the 2nd Floor to the search room via gurney. In the Search room, Maradiaga was medically evaluated for his minor abrasions to the left eye by Nurse and treated on the scene. IP Maradiaga was then removed from the gurney. I helped by supporting his legs with my hands and we placed him prone on the floor. We changed his clothing into jail-issued green clothing. I assisted by removing his pants and placing jail-issued green pants on him. I then assisted in placing Maradiaga back onto the gurney by supporting his legs with my hands. We escorted him to the 5th Floor via gurney. We arrived to cell in Module D. Deputies removed him from the gurney, and I moved the gurney out of the way. I had no further contact with IP Maradiaga. Maradiaga flexed his left arm, and delivered two strikes with my left knee to Maradiagas left side of his body. I assisted Maradiaga off the gurney and onto the cell floor by supporting the feet and ankles with my hands. Maradiaga was placed in a prone position. As I attempted to remove the leg chains, Maradiaga began thrashing his legs around. I applied downward pressure on Maradiagas feet with both of my hands. I applied pressure for approximately 10 seconds. Maradiaga stopped resisting, and the leg chain was removed. Once the leg chains were removed, Maradiaga thrashed his legs. I continued applying downward pressure with my hands until Deputy Weldon 4534 took control of the legs. I exited the cell, followed by my partners, and the door was secured. I had no further contact with Maradiaga. San Diego County Sheriffs Department Officer Report caDEventNo. E9081221 CaseNo. 24107659 ReportNo. 148564 GENERAL CASE INFORMATION 1173 Front St,San 1173 Front St,San Diego, CA 92101 2/24/2024 3:45:00 PM (Saturda Jurisdiction: Beat: Call Source: (and Between): DETENTION FACILITY - CENTRAL a ee Name: Person Code: Interpreter Language: Maradiaga, Jose Eduardo ALIAS / AKA / NICKNAME / MONIKER: Res. Country: County Residence: Undocumented: US - UNITED STATES ienesdent __f Date 7 Birth / 8 Height. Weight: Hair Color: Eye Color Facial Hair- Complexion: Self CONTACT INFORMATION TG DDENTCATION. Injury: Extent Of Treatment: Violent Crime Circumstances: Yes 2 - Treated at Scene Laceration to face, bruising to face Officer Injury Description: Pain, brusing and soreness to right hand pinky finger / Scratches to left side of upper chest / Scrapes and pain to both knees / Redness and soreness to face REPORT NARRATIVE ORIGIN: On 02/24/2024, was assigned to the Contraband and Narcotics Interdiction Team (CNIT) Intake Deputy position at the San Diego Central Jail (SDCJ) when contacted Incarcerated Person (IP) Maradiaga, Jose BN 24707521. DEPUTYS OBSERVATIONS AND ACTIONS: At approximately 1543 hours, contacted Maradiaga in Transfer Holding 10 on the 1st Floor of SDCJ. Maradiaga needed to be escorted to the 2nd Floor to continue the booking process. In my prior contacts with Maradiaga during safety checks and meal servings, Maradiaga was compliant with my instructions. opened the cell door slightly to evaluate Maradiagas compliance. Maradiaga appeared compliant, and escorted him out of the cell. To maintain control of Maradiaga, grabbed hold of Maradiagas arm and guided him to the 1st Floor IP elevator well. At approximately 1545 hours, escorted Maradiaga into Elevator 3. Once inside the elevator, Maradiaga immediately attempted to turn his body towards me. To prevent Maradiaga from facing me, pushed Maradiaga into the elevator wall using both hands on his upper back and arm. The force was ineffective as Maradiaga continued to push himself off the wall and face me. gave Maradiaga numerous commands to stop, which he refused. After Maradiaga continued not to follow my instructions and attempted to face me, determined would place him in handcuffs to control him. ordered Maradiaga to put his hands behind his back, but he refused. As grabbed Maradiagas right arm and attempted to pull it behind his back, Maradiaga suddenly cocked his right elbow back in my direction to strike me. Simultaneously, Maradiaga turned his body toward me. Due to Maradiagas assaultive behavior, utilizing both of my hands to Maradiagas upper body, pulled him and took him to the floor of the elevator. Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH0641 - VALENZUELA, ADRIAN 142 / SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail $H3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR 2/25/2024 6:38:25 AM $H0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 2/27/2024 1:33:21 PM NetRMS_CASDOR rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:16 PM San Diego County Sheriffs Department Officer Report 2 Page 2 of 2 CAD Event No. E9081221 Case No. 24107659 Report No. 148564 Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH0641 - VALENZUELA, ADRIAN 142 / SDCJ - San Diego Central Jail SH3223 - CARDOZA, CESAR Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 2/25/2024 6:38:25 AM SH0814 - MARTINEZ, 053715 2/27/2024 1:33:21 PM NetRMS_CASDOR.rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: March 5, 2024 - 3:16 PM Maradiaga initially landed on the left side of his body. To gain control of Maradiagas head, I applied downward pressure with both hands to the right side of his face. The force was ineffective as Maradiaga rolled onto his back. As Maradiaga rolled onto his back, I immediately felt him strike me with a closed fist, which contacted my face. Simultaneously, I felt Maradiaga attempt to wrap his legs around mine. While Maradiaga began to assault me, I was in a locked elevator with no immediate assistance from deputies. While in motion, the elevator cannot open manually and must be opened by the Central Command Center (CCC). To defend myself from Maradiagas attack, I delivered three (3) closed-fist strikes with my right hand to Maradiagas face. As I struck Maradiaga, he continued to strike me, kick me, and begin to pull the shoulder area of my duty vest towards his body. As he attacked me, I felt Maradiagas fists or elbows contact my face and upper body several times. Fearing for my safety, being in a locked elevator, Maradiaga retaliating and continuing to strike me, I struck Maradiaga approximately eleven (11) additional times with my right fist. At this time, the elevator arrived on the 2nd Floor, and the door was opened. Deputy Ordonez 2545 entered the elevator and assisted me (See Deputy Ordonezs Officer Report). Maradiaga continued to attempt to assault me by trying to strike me with his fists. Additionally, I observed Maradiaga also attempt to assault Deputy Ordonez. Maradiaga rolled himself onto his right side and continued to ignore numerous orders from deputies to stop resisting. Due to Maradiagas continued assaultive behavior, I delivered a knee strike with my right knee to Maradiagas buttocks area. The force was ineffective as Maradiaga continued to attempt to strike my partners and I. Because of Maradiagas continued assaultive behavior and attempts to injure me, I delivered approximately four (4) additional closed-fist strikes to Maradiagas head area, which were ineffective. The use of force and attack from Maradiaga occurred inside the elevator. Due to the elevator being a small, confined space, Maradiaga was holding onto my duty vest and continuing to attack me; I could not disengage to assess other force options or remove myself to transition to a different force option on my duty belt. Additional deputies arrived on scene and pulled Maradiaga out of the elevator and into the 2nd Floor IP elevator well. Despite additional deputies arriving on scene, Maradiaga continued to resist deputies by not following our orders, attempting to grab onto deputies, and thrashing his body around. Because of his continued assaultive behavior, I delivered approximately two more (2) knee strikes with my right knee to Maradiagas buttocks. To gain pain compliance from Maradiaga, I applied a bent wrist lock to Maradiagas left hand with my hands. Simultaneously, I applied downward pressure, utilizing my left knee to Maradiagas buttocks. The force was effective as Maradiaga slowly began to comply with instructions. Had we not used force, Maradiaga may have continued to assault my partners or me. Eventually, deputies were able to gain complete control of Maradiaga and place him in handcuffs. Once a medical gurney arrived on scene, I supported Maradiagas legs and assisted him onto the medical gurney. Maradiaga was placed in the prone position, and the safety straps were secured. Once Maradiaga was secured on the medical gurney, I removed myself from the scene to assess my injuries and had no further contact with him. Immediately, I felt pain and observed swelling in my right pinky finger, pain on the side of my right hand, pain and scrapes to both of my knees, pain in my face, and burning to my chest area. Due to the injuries I sustained from Maradiagas attack, I was sent to the hospital for treatment. Body-Worn Camera (BWC) footage of this incident was captured. BACKGROUND: Anderson, Ryan was arrested by San Diego Police Department on 10/10/2023 for; (ae DEPUTYS OBSERVATIONS AND ACTIONS: entered Quad 106 and called for I/P Anderson, Ryan BN 23741609. asked him if he wanted to take his court medication. He raised his voice at me and said, Im not going to fucking court today! told him to calm down and asked him why he didnt want to go to court. Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By 133 / GBDF - George Bailey $H4398 - GONZALEZ, CARLOS Detention Facility SH7800 - ROMERO, GEORGE 10/27/2023 10:06:00 PM 12/8/2023 10:36:49 PM NetRMS_CASDOR. rif v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: December 22, 2023 - 11:40 AM San Diego County Sheriffs Department Officer Report 2 Page 2 of 3 CAD Event No. E8862563 Case No. 23145567 Report No. 144724 Reporting Officer Division / Organization Reviewed By SH4398 - GONZALEZ, CARLOS 133 / GBDF - George Bailey Detention Facility SH7800 - ROMERO, GEORGE Report Date Detective Assigned Reviewed Date 10/27/2023 10:06:00 PM 12/8/2023 10:36:49 PM NetRMS_CASDOR.rtf v11-15-06 Printed By SH2821 Printed: December 22, 2023 - 11:40 AM Anderson is approximately 61 300 lbs. Due to his size and agitated state I felt I would need at least another deputy to reason and escort Anderson to court holding in order to avoid any potential issues. At approximately 0400 hours Deputies Sosa 3509, Castillo 4897, and Rondero-Rojo 4336, and I entered House 1B Module to speak to Anderson about his court refusal. To see if Anderson would react differently to another Deputy I stepped to the side and let Deputy Sosa speak to Anderson. Deputy Sosa let Anderson know it was time to go to court. Anderson complied with Deputy Sosas instruction but was groaning and mumbling incoherent words. The muscles in his face were tense and his face was red. Anderson put on his jail issued blues and stated, I dont know why you guys are fucking making me do this, I dont want to go to fucking court. Deputy Sosa explained to him it is a part of jail operations and we are doing our job. Deputy Sosa convinced him to leave the quad. Anderson walked out of the module on his own with his cane. We escorted Anderson outside of the module. Once we arrived at the House Corridor he stopped walking, turned around and faced me and said, I dont have to go to fucking court. I told him to face away and keep walking or else I would place him in handcuffs for not obeying my instructions. Anderson complied. He turned around and walked down towards GBDF Processing. During our escort to GBDF Processing, Anderson said Youre a bitch for this. He continued cursing specifically at me and called me a bitch a couple more times. Once we arrived at Processing, Deputy Sosa instructed Anderson to face the wall and stop talking, while we determined which holding cell he would be secured in. Anderson ignored Deputy Sosas instructions and turned to face me. Anderson tensed up his body and said, You aint nothing but a bitch. After that he took a bladed stance, stared at me and said, Take off your badge and lets see what youre about. I instructed him to turn around and face the wall. Anderson then quickly raised his arms with closed fists and lunged towards me with his upper body as if he was going to attack me. In order to prevent Anderson from assaulting me I delivered an elbow strike to his face. I saw that Anderson raised his arms and I felt he might try to strike me. To stop him from doing this I delivered two closed fist strikes to his face. The first strike was with my left hand and the next one was with my right hand on the left side of his face. Deputies Sosa and Castillo grabbed Anderson by an arm on each side. I grabbed Anderson on the back of the neck and shoulder area. I applied downward pressure to push him to the floor. I gave verbal commands to stop resisting as I felt his body tense up as I pushed him to the floor. My force was successful in preventing Anderson from assaulting me or any of the other deputies present. We were able to force Anderson onto the floor. Once on the floor Anderson was compliant. Deputies Mccullen 3124 Enciso 6191 Denison 3743 and Calderon 4384, who were assigned to Processing were present during the incident. Deputies Mccullen and Enciso handcuffed Anderson. Anderson continued to be compliant. At approximately 0410 hours, Sgt. Romero 7800 arrived on scene and was informed about the incident. GBDF Health staff and a gurney was requested to processing. Once they arrived, Deputies Mccullen, Calderon, and Denison assisted Anderson onto the gurney. Anderson rolled himself to his side. Deputy McCullen took hold of Andersons left arm and Deputy Denison took hold of Andersons right arm and assisted him to his feet. Once Anderson was on his feet, he sat on the gurney. Deputy Calderon grabbed Andersons right shoulder and helped Anderson slide higher on the gurney as he was in the seated position. Deputy McCullen was the safety deputy during the escort to medical. Deputies Do 0361 and Robledo 4453, who were assigned to GBDF Medical escorted Anderson to the GBDF Medical where he was evaluated and treated by GBDF Health staff. Anderson was then transported to the Alvarado Hospital via Ambulance for further evaluation and treatment. At 0500 hours, I went to Concentra Urgent Care for evaluation and was treated for my injured right thumb. I had no further contact with Anderson. At approximately 0500 hours on 10/28/2023 I uploaded the digital photographs and CCTV footage of the incident onto a compact disc for evidence. I submitted all related evidence into GBDF Evidence locker 12. DEPUTYS OBSERVATIONS AND ACTIONS: At approximately 0400 hours, Deputy Castillo 4897, Gonzalez 4398, Sosa 3509, and were escorting I/P Anderson to processing after hed initially refused to go to court. Once on the floor removed Deputy Gonzalez from the use of force because he had injured his hand and walked him to GBDF medical. had no further contact with I/P Anderson. BN - Booking Number 23741609 Po CCU CCS Extent Of Treatment: Violent Cnme Circumstances: Subject Injury Description: Officer Injury Description: REPORT NARRATIVE Origin: On 10/26/2023, was assigned to work the Northside Sergeant position at the George Bailey Detention Facility (GBDF), when heard a radio call for assistance of GBDF medical staff to the Court Processing area. Deputys Observations and Actions: At approximately 0412 hours, arrived at the GBDF Court Processing area to see an Incarcerated Person (IP) later identified as Ryan Anderson BK23741609, on the floor with handcuffs on. Deputy McCullen 3124 advised me a use of force occurred with Anderson and escorting deputies. Deputies assisted Anderson onto a gurney and GBDF Medical staff started assessing Anderson for any injuries. GBDF Medical staff asked deputies to move Anderson to the Medical Dispensary to better assess Anderson. The deputies moved Anderson to the Medical Dispensary. walked to the Watch Commanders office to retrieve a digital recorder so may interview Anderson about the use of force that just occurred. At about 0425, conducted a recorded interview with Anderson in the GBDF Medical Dispensary. Anderson said he was offered his court medications but refused. He also told the deputies in the house that he refused to go to court. After talking to a couple of the housing deputies he decided to go to court. Anderson said while in the sallyport he was calling the deputies names and turned towards one of the deputies (Deputy Gonzalez 4398) and said, What are you going to do about it? While facing Deputy Gonzalez, Anderson put his foot forward. Anderson said, I intimidated him. He got scared like a little bitch and assaulted me. asked Anderson if he took a fighting stance. Anderson said he took a defensive stance. Anderson said he didnt want to g to El Cajon court because its an all-day process and he didnt want to wait. Anderson claimed the deputy struck him ten times with his right hand. concluded my interview and had no further contact with Anderson. Reporting Officer Reviewed By 133 / 133 / GBDF . FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: June 19, 2024 Incident: Officer Involved Shooting (OIS) Update 1 Date/Time: June 16, 2024, at approximately 9:00 a.m. Location: 44000 block of Osgood Road Media Contact: FremontPDPIOfremont.gov June 16, 2024 Officer Involved Shooting (OIS) Update 1 On June 16, 2024, at approximately 9:00 a.m., Fremont Police Officers responded to a carjacking in the parking lot of a store on the 44000 block of Osgood Road. The suspect was armed with a knife and left the scene prior to officers arrival. A short time later, an officer located a male subject nearby who matched the description of the carjacking suspect. The suspect was still armed with a knife and walking on Automall Parkway just west of Osgood Rd. The officer directed the suspect to stop. The suspect brandished the knife at the officer and advanced toward him. Despite numerous commands to stop, and the officer repositioning to create space and distance, the suspect continued to advance toward the officer while holding the knife. The officer discharged his service weapon, striking the suspect once. Officers on scene rendered medical aid to the suspect, who was subsequently transported to an area hospital. The suspect is currently in stable condition. No officers were injured in this event. Involved Fremont Police Officer: Officer Jonathan Laforteza, two years of service in law enforcement, with almost a year of service with the Fremont Police Department. Officer Laforteza is assigned to patrol. Suspect: Sean Patrick McMahan, 31 years old, out of Fremont. The Fremont Police Department Crime Against Persons Unit is investigating this incident. It remains an active and ongoing investigation. In the coming days, additional cases involving criminal charges against the suspect will be presented to the Alameda County District Attorneys Office. Fremont Police Department is currently developing an indepth, detailed release of information, to include body-worn camera video, store surveillance video, and evidence of the related crimes. This information is anticipated to be available and released in the near future. Anyone who witnessed the incident or with information regarding the incident, please contact Detective Michael Gebhardt at mgebhardtfremont.gov or by calling our Investigations Unit at (510) 790-6900 . We also accept anonymous tips. Text Tip FremontPD followed by your short message to 888-777 or via the web at https://www.fremontpolice.gov/TIP. - - P o l i c e D e p a r t m e n t Press Release

KNOW YOUR RIGHTS UNDER THE SUNSHINE ORDINANCE Governments duty is to serve the public, reaching its decisions in full view of the public. Commissions, boards, councils, and other agencies of the City and County exist to conduct the peoples business. This ordinance assures that deliberations are conducted before the people and that City operations are open to the peoples review. For information on your rights under the Sunshine Ordinance (Chapters 67 of the San Francisco Administrative Code) or to report a violation of the ordinance, please contact: Sunshine Ordinance Task Force Administrator in Room 244 at City Hall, 1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place, San Francisco, CA 94102-4683. (Office) 415-554-7724; (Fax) 415-554-7854; E-mail: SOTFsfgov.org. Copies of the Sunshine Ordinance can be obtained from the Clerk of the Sunshine Task Force, the San Francisco Public Library and on the Citys website at www.sfgov.org. Copies of explanatory documents are available to the public online at http://www.sfbos.org/sunshine or, upon request to the Commission Secretary, at the above address or phone number. LANGUAGE ACCESS Per the Language Access Ordinance (Chapter 91 of the San Francisco Administrative Code), Chinese, Spanish and or Filipino (Tagalog) interpreters will be available upon requests. Meeting Minutes may be translated, if requested, after they have been adopted by the Commission. Assistance in additional languages may be honored whenever possible. To request assistance with these services please contact the Police Commission at (v) 415.837.7070 at least 48 hours in advance of the hearing. Late requests will be honored if possible. DISABILITY ACCESS Police Commission hearings are held in Room 400 at City Hall, 1 Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett Place in San Francisco. City Hall is accessible to persons using wheelchairs and other assistive mobility devices. Ramps are available at the Grove, Van Ness and McAllister entrances. The closest accessible BART station is Civic Center Station. For information about SFMTA service, please call 311. This meeting will be broadcast and captioned on SFGovTV. Assistive listening devices, real time captioning, American Sign Language interpreters, readers, large print agendas or other accommodations are available upon request. Please make your requests for accommodations to the Police Commission at (v) 415.837.7070. Requesting sign language accommodations at least 4 business days prior to the meeting will help to ensure availability. Allowing a minimum of 48 business hours for all other accommodation requests (for example, for other auxiliary aids and services) helps ensure availability. To request accommodation, please contact SFPD Commission Officer, sfpd.commissionsfgov.org, 415-837-7070. Remote public participation is available upon request for individuals who cannot attend in person due to disability. Making a request to participate remotely no later than one (1) hour prior to the start of the meeting helps ensure availability of the meeting link. LOBBYIST ORDINANCE Individuals and entities that influence or attempt to influence local legislative or administrative action may be required by the San Francisco Lobbyist Ordinance SF Campaign & Governmental Conduct Code 2.100 to register and report lobbying activity. For more information about the Lobbyist Ordinance, please contact the San Francisco Ethics Commission at 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 220, San Francisco, CA 94102; (Office) 415.252.3100; (Fax) 415.252.3112; Website: sfgov.org/ethics.

Calexico Police Department Supplemental Report Incident Report Number. neidiea Incident Date: Calexico, CA, 92231 New Incident: Original Offense - t: eB Body Worn Camera Used NARRATIVE On Tuesday, February 27, 2024, (Sgt. Miguel Carbajal) was on duty with the Calexico Police Department assigned to uniformed patrol as the night shift supervisor. At about 19:00 hours, was briefed that Christian Plancarte had been medically cleared from a San Diego Hospital and was being transported back to Calexico by U.S. Marshals. At about 20:00 hours, Deputy U.S. Marshal Patrick OLeary and Oliver Shi arrived at the Calexico Police Department and turned over custody of Plancarte to me. Plancarte was moved to a interview room for question. then read Plancarte his Miranda Rights using my department issued Miranda warning Card. Plancarte answered yes to understanding his rights and requested to speak with an attorney. No statements were collected. U.S. Marshals also turned over Plancartes clothing. took custody of a bloody white torn shirt and blue underwear. The shirt and underwear were collected for evidentiary purposes and booked into a evidence locker. Plancarte was later booked at Imperial County Jail. REPORTING OFFICER SIGNATURE / DATE Michael Ahern 2099 Aug 14, 2023 08:07 (e-signature) SUPERVISOR SIGNATURE / DATE Derrek Dagneau 2168 Aug 17, 2023 14:59 (e-signature) PRINT NAME Michael Ahern 2099 PRINT NAME Derrek Dagneau 2168 Less Lethal Weapons Systems: Those munitions that can be fired, launched, or otherwise propelled for the purpose of engaging compliance, overcoming resistance, or preventing serious injury without posing a significant potential for causing death. The circumstances justifying the use of less lethal weapons systems include, but are not limited to: 1.Restoration or maintenance of order during jail or civil disturbances 2.Safely controlling non-compliant/violent persons. 3.Situations where the first line supervisor or Commanding Officer deem necessary to safely resolve the incident with a lesser potential of serious injury to citizens and deputies. As a less lethal weapons operator, I carried the following: Sting Ball Grenade, which is a is a device that delivers rubber pellets, a bright flash and sound. The Sting Ball Grenade is commonly used as a crowd management tool. The Sting Ball Grenade has an initial 1.5 second delay that initiates fuze assembly separation, followed by another .5 second delay before the blast which is sufficient to project the rubber balls in an approximate 50 foot radius. A LMT 40mm Less Lethal launcher. The LMT 40mm Less Lethal Launcher is a single shot launcher that fires standard 40mm less lethal ammunition. This ammunition varies from impact munitions, which utilize pain compliance by imparting kinetic energy into a subject, as well as chemical agents, and marking rounds. After I was equipped with the proper munitions for the RIM team, I entered C Pod and waited for the authorization for entry and deployment. Once the RIM team was assembled, they met with me at the upper C Pod passthrough door. Attempts to deescalate with went on for quite some time but subsequently failed. After enough reasonable time had passed for de-escalation, authorization was given for entry into D pod. In accordance with department General Orders 1.05, 21.01.01, and 1.21, along with the RIM team, I obtained authorization from Lieutenant J. Atienza to enter D Pod and deploy a Sting Ball Grenade to distract and gain control of the situation safely. I placed the Sting Ball Grenade at the D pod door where focused his attention. The Sting Ball Grenade was an effective deployment and appeared to distract and guide away from the damaged pod door. We executed a dynamic entry to gain access to D pod. Our primary concern was to deescalate violent behavior and detain him without further incident. I moved downstairs to the first level of the pod and accessed the LMT 40mm Less Lethal Launcher. I gave several lawful orders to get on the ground but he refused. put himself between the D/E pod wall and the D pod benches. is a sophisticated fighter and I believed he put himself in this position to help create a position of advantage for himself and disadvantage for us. knows it is easier to fight deputies in confined spaces rather than open spaces. Deputy Gregoire vocalized the bite numerous times to alert his partners. For about two minutes, deputies had been struggling to gain control of on the ground. is a patient and intelligent fighter. Once he has the opportunity, he will quickly use any window of opportunity to assault staff. If has an unrestrained limb, he will use it to assault staff. At this point, I wanted to ensure we reduced any further risk of injury to deputies and I wanted to be incapacitated so he had absolutely no opportunity to assault staff, bite staff, or gain control of our less lethal weapons. With the amount of deputies that were attempting to overcome resistance, I was concerned about potential injuries could have sustained during the incident which included unnecessary back/neck injury and positional asphyxiation. Based on the totality of circumstances which included sophistication and his ability to assault staff on the ground, unrestrained and even restrained, I believed deploying the taser was our best option to overcome his resistance and prevent any further significant injury to him and deputies. I believed neuromuscular incapacitation which is defined as causing loss of sufficient voluntary muscle control, which prevents the subject from advancing and achieving their goal. At this point, needed to be moved to the Santa Rita Jail Out-Patient Housing Unit (OPHU) for further medical treatment and four-hour observation pursuant to agency policy. This behavior continued throughout the transport from the pod to the Housing Unit back hall, and into the OPHU. Once at the OPHU, was still uncooperative. refused medical treatment and would not allow me to take detailed digital photographs to document his physical condition. Deputies were able to move into cell 11 at the OPHU. Once he was in the cell, the deputies exited and were followed by as he crawled on the floor towards the opened cell door. Deputies attempted to close the door, but put his feet in the door jam. Sergeant Latu, who was on scene, attempted to push his feet back in the cell. kicked Sergeant Latu. To prevent further assaultive behavior, I accessed my TASER and activated the arc feature in hopes to gain compliance from I was unsuccessful and moved my TASER towards his shin. The drive stun was effective and stopped kicking deputies. then extended his leg again towards the door frame and I activated by TASER once more and put it towards him. I am unsure if I made contact again before he pulled his leg back. I was unable to confirm with if I made two complete contacts with him based on his lack of cooperation. The door was closed without further incident. I was not injured during this incident. I also took photographs of the damaged caused by The photographs were later annotated and uploaded to the secure server. Sergeant Dagneau and Lieutenant Atiezna were notified of my uses of force. I later placed the expended TASER cartridges into evidence. The TASER report was uploaded to www.evidence.com. This is a supplemental report to 23-011313. IMPERIAL COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 940 Main Street, Suite 102 El Centro, CA 92243 INVESTIGATION REPORT Christian Plancarte Officer Involved Shooting 02/23/2024 Ol Initial Response 24-01548 Orlando Espino Calexico Police Department 24-001058 SUMMARY: On February 21, 2024, at approximately 10:04 p.m., the Calexico Police Department (CPD) requested the Imperial County District Attorney (ICDA) Bureau of Investigation (BOI) investigate an Officer Involved shooting (OIS that involved one of their officers who discharged their weapon at a subject. The OIS occurred at a Calexico, CA, 92231 and involved officers from CPD. This report documents the initial notification and request for assistance by CPD to ICDA-BOI Commander (Cmdr.) O. Espino. Below is a summary of the investigative actions taken by Cmdr O. Espino. DETAILS OF INVESTIGATION: Notification: On February 21, 2024, at about 10:04 p.m., I, Cmdr. Orlando Espino, received a telephone call from CPD Chief of Police (COP) A. Orozco advising CPD was involved in an officer involved shooting and that the Imperial County District Attorneys Office was being requested to conduct the investigation. reached out to ICDA-BOI Chief Investigator Justin Matus, who instructed CPD to contact the California Department of Justice (CAL DOJ) in accordance with AB 1506. I subsequently relayed this information to COP Orozco and directed him to contact CAL DOJ, providing him with the necessary contact details. After a brief period, COP Orozco informed me that Special Agent Sean Richardson from CAL DOJ had advised him to refer the incident to ICDA. Following this, I contacted Chief Matus, Cmdr. Armstrong, and DAIs Victor Dominguez, Marco Lopez, Albert Llanas, and Rafael Peraza. Arrival: At approximately 11:00 p.m., reached the general vicinity of the Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) and was met away from the OIS scene by COP Orozco and Sergeant (Sgt.) M. Carbajal. From my vantage point, observed CPD had secured the area with yellow tape and had assigned a CPD Ofc. to monitor the scene with a log. I then inquired about the status of the public safety statement and COP Orozco confirmed that it had been furnished to Sgt. Carbajal. He then proceeded to brief the following: Ofc. Hernandez and Sgt. Carbajal were dispatched TTD -carding a reported burglary. Upon arrival, they observed a familiar male, identified as CHRISTIAN Plancarte, whom they had encountered on multiple occasions at that location. According to COP Orozco, CHRISTIAN approached Sgt. Carbajal wielding a crowbar IMPERIAL COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 940 Main Street, Suite 102 El Centro, CA 92243 INVESTIGATION REPORT Investigation Title: CHRISTIAN PLANCARTE BOI: 24-001058-1 in an apparent attempt to strike him. Officer Hernandez then discharged his weapon three times, hitting CHRISTIAN once in the torso, grazing his leg, and striking a vehicle in the driveway. Following the incident, CHRISTIAN received first aid from Sgt. Carbajal, Ofc. Hernandez, and Ofc. Torres before being taken to a hospital by the Calexico Fire Department. I subsequently departed from the scene and awaited the arrival of the responding ICDA DAIs. Prior to my arrival, CPD requested the Imperial County Sheriffs Office (ICSO) Scientific Investigations Unit (SIU) assistance in processing both the officers and scene. Investigator note: On February 26, 2024, at approximately 11:45 a.m., I called COP Orozco and asked if (on the date of the OIS) he instructed Ofc. Hernandez and Sgt Carbajal to not discuss the incident with anyone except union representatives or DAIs. COP Orozco replied he had not. Briefing: At approximately 12:00 a.m., COP Orozco and Sgt Carbajal met with the following DAIs and provided a in depth briefing: Chief Investigator Matus, Cmdr Armstrong, Dominguez, Lopez, Llanas, Peraza, and me. They related the following: Officer A. Hernandez and Sgt. M. Carbajal were dispatched t egarding a burglary in progress. Upon their arrival, they identified a male individual, CHRISTIAN Plancarte, whom they had encountered multiple times at that address. Considering CHRISTIANs history of law enforcement interactions and previous arrests, CPD was aware of his mental health issues and tendency to display aggression during such encounters. CPD was also aware the reporting was his elderly mother who they believed was hiding in one of the rooms inside the house. CPD also mentioned there had been restraining orders prohibiting CHRISTIAN from the residence but were not sure if they had expired or were active. As they approached the scene, they heard loud banging noises emanating from the residence, and observed CHRISTIAN violently attempting to enter the residence through the front door. Subsequently, CHRISTIAN charged towards Sgt Carbajal raising the crowbar as if it were a baseball bat, aiming to strike him. Officer A. Hernandez responded by discharging his weapon three times; hitting CHRISTIAN once in the torso, grazing his leg, striking a nearby vehicle, and ultimately causing CHRISTIAN to collapse in the driveway. Shortly after, Ofe A. Torres arrived on scene. Following the incident, Sgt. Carbajal, Ofc. Hernandez, and Ofc. Torres administered first aid to CHRISTIAN before he was transported to a hospital. They also indicated CPD Ofcs had interviewed a witness and had canvassed the area. Finally, it was mentioned that Ofc. C. Fraker, PY and a third individual identified as a. mother, were currently inside the residence with the reporting party. and her mother had a familial relationship with CHRISTIAN as iiwas dating CHRISTIAN brother. Page 2 of 3 IMPERIAL COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 940 Main Street, Suite 102 El Centro, CA 92243 INVESTIGATION REPORT Investigation Title: CHRISTIAN PLANCARTE BOI: 24-001058-1 Officer Processing: Investigator note: I recorded this portion of the investigation with my Body Worn Camera (BWC) and subsequently uploaded the data into evidence.com. Below is a summary of the investigation and interview. For more specific information or exact quotes not listed in this report, please refer to the data on evidence.com. Following the briefing, DAI R. De la Rosa and I proceeded to CPD (420 E. Fifth Street, Calexico, CA, 92231) where we convened with SIU Technician J. Castro to facilitate the processing of Ofc. A. Hernandez. Additionally, present at CPD were Sgt. Sean Sundahl and Ofc. Gabriella Torres, who served as Ofc. A. Hernandezs Peer Support and Union Representative. For additional details, please refer to DAI De la Rosas and SIU Castros evidence report. At approximately 1:30 a.m., I returned to the OIS scene and provided general assistance until the scene was closed at approximately 4:00 a.m. End of Report Investigation continues. O- 30 Dad RLANDO ESPINO, COMMANDER DATE Page 3 of 3

During my shift was wearing a Body Worn Camera (BWC) and my patrol vehicle (178) was equipped with an In-Car Camera (ICC).Both were tested for functionality at the beginning of my shift, and both were operating during the incident documented in this report. At approximately 0224 hours, was dispatched to the call of a suspicious person at Elk Grove, CA 95757. The reporting party, (R-1, S-2) Eunice APPLING, called and stated that an unknown subject was banging on her door and they have been there for about five minutes. Further, APPLING said the subject was kicking her door. Dispatch advised that APPLING was yelling at the subject to get away from the door. APPLING could be heard by Dispatch yelling at the subject that the door was kicked in. Shortly after, APPLING disconnected the phone call. APPLING was asked by dispatch twice if she had any idea who the subject was and APPLING stated no. Shortly after, heard Officer Rodriguez (B21) advise over the radio that he arrived on scene and heard screaming. Following, Officer Rodriguez advised that he had one person at gunpoint. At approximately 0230 hours, arrived on scene and made my way into the residence with Officer Hanna (B31). entered the residence, and encountered APPLING standing near the front door. was acting hysterical and crying. made my way further into the residence to locate Officer Rodriguez and observed Officer Crain and Officer Rodriguez attempting to detain an adult male, later identified as (S-1) Leroy DANIELS. DANIELS was lying face down on the ground. Officer Rodriguez and Officer Crian were attempting to place DANIELS in handcuffs as DANIELS actively resisted their efforts. held DANELs legs as Officer Crain and Officer Rodriguez placed him in handcuffs. While Officers were detaining DANIELS, could hear DANIELS state that he could not breathe. Once he was placed in handcuffs, rolled DANIELS onto his side and into the recovery position. observed that DANIELS was bleeding from his face and that there was blood on the carpet. After, DANIELS was placed inside of a patrol vehicle and Identified DANIELS by his California drivers license that was in his possession. later took photos of the scene, broken door frame, and blood on the floor. later uploaded the photos to Axon Evidence. conducted a protective sweep of the residence and located three juveniles in a room near the front of the residence. The juveniles were later determined to be APPLINGs children, and they stated they did not need medical attention. contacted APPLING inside the residence. APPLING verbally identified herself as Eunice APPLING. stated the following to me in summary: REPORTING OFFICER SIGNATURE / DATE SUPERVISOR SIGNATURE / DATE JOHN TAYLOR 10832 Sep 23, 2023 22:35 (e-signature) SCOTT WESSEL 10754 Sep 23, 2023 22:41 (e- signature) PRINT NAME PRINT NAME JOHN TAYLOR 10832 SCOTT WESSEL 10754 Elk Grove Police Department Pg 1 of 4 Mark43 RMS Form v2.0 generated by S. I just wanted you guys to tell him to calm down and to go for the night. They just hit him for no reason. I don want to press any charges. Me and my husband had a minor argument and things got out of control. He just got back from the club. Me and my husband have been married for about 10 years and we live here together. He wasnt at home and I was at home. We got into an argument over the phone. He came home from the club and I locked him out. I locked the front door and I was holding the front door closed. He got into the house and we went into our room so the kids wouldnt hear us. The kids were in another room and weren around. Thats when you guys came in. He didnt hit me or anything. We were just arguing. I provoked the argument. I dont want to press charges. I dont want him to go to jail. The police came running in with guns and pointed guns at him. We were in the room arguing. The police said come out with your hands up. My husband told them to the fuck out of my house. I told them to please don shoot my husband. They told me to move to the side and I said no, please don shoot him. My husband was standing behind me. The officer told him to stand there with your hands up. My husband said you are in my fucking house?. That when the officer hit him, slammed him against the wall, and slammed him onto the ground. END OF STATEMENT While speaking with APPLING, I did not observe any visible injuries on her. APPLING denied medical care. I asked APPLING if I could take photos of her to document her nonexistent visible injuries, however, APPLING did not consent. I informed Officer Rodriguez of APPLINGs statement. While informing Officer Rodriguez, Officer Hanna spoke with APPLING. See Officer Hannas supplemental report for further details. I observed the front door and door frame to the residence. I observed the door frame was damaged, cracked and broken. There were fresh drywall particles on the ground near the broken door frame that were consistent with the front door being forced open. The front door of the residence had what appeared to be scuff marks near the center of the door. I did not observe any dents in the front door. I took photos of the door and frame and later uploaded them to Axon Evidence. Officer Rodriguez advised me he was placing DANIELS under arrest. Officer Hanna transported DANIELS to Kaiser South Permanente hospital to be medically evaluated. I followed Officer Hanna to the hospital and contacted DANIELS. I read DANIELS his miranda rights verbatim from my department issued miranda card. DANIELS stated yeah that he understood each of his rights. DANIELS stated that he did not want to talk to me. IMPERIAL COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 940 Main Street, Suite 102 El Centro, CA 92243 INVESTIGATION REPORT PLANCARTE, Christian Officer Involved Shooting February 21, 2024 010 Officers Interview ICDA BOI 24-01548 Rafael Peraza Calexico Police Department Calexico PD 24-001058 SUMMARY: Attorneys Bureau of Investigation investigate an officer involved shooting that occurred at treet in the City of El Calexico and involved an officer from the Calexico Police Department. On February 21, 2024, the Calexico Police Department requested the Imperial County fl The following report documents the interview of Calexico Police Officer Alexander Hernandez and a review of the Officer Hernandez Body Worn Camera (BWC) footage. DETAILS OF INVESTIGATION: On Monday February 26, 2024, at approximately 1245 hours, Imperial County District Attorneys Office (ICDAO) Investigator M. Lopez and I, District Attorney Investigator (DAI) Rafael Peraza, conducted a voluntary interview with Calexico Police Officer (CPD) Alexander Hernandez, badge number 547. The interview was conducted at the CPD Chiefs Office conference room. Also present during the interview were CPD Sergeant Sean Acuna and Matthew H. Gelfond, Attorney with Rains Lucia Stern Law Firm. The following is only a summary of the statements made by Officer Hernandez during the interview. For a complete and thorough portrayal of the voluntary interview, please refer to the audio recording of Officer Hernandez interview uploaded to evidence.com. During Officer HERNANDEZ voluntary interview, he was asked if he had reviewed any audio or video recordings of the incident and Officer HERNANDEZ answered, Yes, Officer HERNANDEZ stated he had not discussed the incident with anyone other than his counsel. Officer Background Information Officer HERNANDEZ has been in law enforcement for approximately one (1) year and ten (10) months. Officer HERNANDEZ worked for the Bell Gardens Police Department for four (4) months and one (1) year and six (6) months with CPD. Miguel Carbajal, Calexico Police Department Sergeant Sean Acuna, who was acting in an administrative capacity, and Attorney Matt Gelfond, who is representing Sgt. Carbajal. Carbajal if he has had an opportunity to review any video and audio recordings or any reports prior to speaking to us and he stated that he did. At this point DAI Peraza advised Sgt. Carbajal to go ahead and tell us about the OIS that occurred on 2/21/24. Sgt. Carbajal stated he was on duty when the initial call came out. He stated officers were dispatched to es: reference to residential burglary in progress. Sgt. Carbajal stated he is familiar with that residence. He stated Calexico Police Department dispatch advised that the reporting party is a female resident who stated her son was trying to break into the residence and she was hiding in the restroom. DETAILS OF INVESTIGATION: Calexico Fire Department Personnel On Friday March 1, 2024, at approximately 0900 hours, DAI Marco Lopez and I contacted five crewmembers of the Calexico Fire Department. Engineer Mathew Bush, Paramedic Joel Rivera, Fire Fighter Eric Espinoza, EMT Edgar Martinez and Fire Captain Juan Contreras. Engine 21 was the first medical unit on the scene of this OIS. Audio-recorded interviews were conducted with four personnel individually. At 0945 hours, I conducted an interview with CFD Engineer Mathew Bush regarding his involvement in this incident. Engineer Bush stated that his role in the incident was limited other than him driving the ambulance to Calexico International Airport (CIA). Engineer Bush told me he did not have any interaction with PLANCARTE. Engineer Bush was asked if PLANCARTE was combative. Engineer Bush just indicated PLANCARTE was complaining of pain. At 0953 hours, I conducted an interview with CFD Firefighter Eric Espinoza regarding his involvement in this incident. Firefighter Espinoza stated they responded to the address 736 Grant refence a medical aid call. When he arrived on scene PLANCARTE was already in the ambulance pending transport. Firefighter Espinoza said he did not have any interaction with PLANCARTE. Firefighter Espinoza was asked if he heard PLANCARTE say why he was shot and if he saw PLANCARTE become combative. Firefighter Espinoza said no. At 1016 hours, I conducted an interview with CFD Firefighter/EMT Edgar Morales regarding his involvement in this incident. Firefighter Morales stated they were dispatched to Grant Street in F-24-01578 229 IMPERIAL COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION 940 Main Street, Suite 102 El Centro, CA 92243 INVESTIGATION REPORT Investigation Title: PLANCARTE, Christian BOI 24-001548 reference to a shots fired call. Firefighter Morales said, Negative. Firefighter Morales was asked if PLANCARTE had become combative. At 1020 hours, I conducted an interview with CFD Firefighter Captain Juan Contreras regarding his involvement in this incident. Cuellar Calexico Police Department 24-001058 SUMMARY On February 21, 2024, Calexico Police Department (CPD) requested assistance from the Imperial County District Attorneys Office (ICDAO), regarding an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) Calexico, California. This Report of Investigation (ROI) documents the interview attempts with Christian Issac PLANCARTE at the University of California San Diego Medical Center, located at 200 W. Arbor Drive, San Diego, California on February 22, 2024 and February 26, 2024. DETAILS OF INVESTIGATION: On February 22, 2024, at 3:56 am, Supervising District Attorney Investigator (SDAI) Carl Armstrong sent an email advising the suspect in an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) was flown to the University of California San Diego (UCSD) Hillcrest, Medical Center, located at 200 W. Arbor Drive, San Diego, California. SDAI Armstrong provided the telephone number to contact the charge nurse and advised that the subject was in surgery. At 7:00 a.m., DAI Contreras conducted a query in Pro Phoenix to obtain the suspects name. Under Calexico case number 24-001058, DAI Contreras learned the suspect to be Christian PLANCARTE with a date of birth of August 25, 1993.
