SHANNAN MOON Sheriff/Coroner Public Administrator NEVADA COUNTY SHERIFFS OFFICE MAIN OFFICE: 950 MAIDU AVE NEVADA CITY, CA 95959 (530) 265-1471 ANIMAL CONTROL: 950 MAIDU AVE NEVADA CITY, CA 95959 (530) 265-1471 CORRECTIONS: P.O. BOX 928 NEVADA CITY, CA 95959 (530) 265-1291 TRUCKEE: 10879 DONNER PASS RD TRUCKEE, CA 96161 (530) 582-7838 June 20, 2024 Officer Arianne Aguirre Nevada County Sheriffs Office 925Maidu Avenue, Nevada City, CA 95959 RE: Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, Reference IA 2023-003 Officer Aguirre: You are hereby notified that the following disciplinary action is being recommended to the Sheriff regarding your position as a Correctional Officer with the Nevada County Sheriffs Office: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT BACKGROUND In June of 2021 you were hired by the Nevada County Sheriffs Office as a Correctional Officer I and were assigned to the Wayne Brown Correctional Facility. You progressed through the jail training program and were granted solo officer status in December of 2021. You completed your CO I probationary period and were promoted to a Correctional Officer II in June of 2022. You were assigned light duty in October of 2023, and then placed on administrative assignment in December of 2023. While on administrative assignment, you resigned from the Sheriffs Office on April 22, 2024. As a Correctional Officer you are responsible for a multitude of duties, which also include some of the following: Reading and understanding department policies, rules, instructions, laws and ordinances. Adopting quick, effective, and reasonable courses of actions while considering surrounding hazards and circumstances. Understanding and following written and oral instructions. Exercising good judgement and making sound decisions under a variety of conditions. Adhere to local, state and federal laws and guidelines. Provide for the safety and security of inmates and other jail staff members. Adhere to your oath of office as a Correctional Officer. Conduct yourself in a manner consistent with this agencys mission statement. Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 2 PERSONNEL FILE REVIEW INVESTIGATION SUMMARY An administrative investigation was conducted by Lieutenant Greene regarding an incident you were involved in on July 4th, 2023. In that investigation you were the suspect of a criminal domestic battery incident that occurred in the City of Grass Valley. During that same investigative period, you were involved in another domestic battery incident that occurred at your residence on July 22, 2023. Your conduct during that incident was also investigated by Lt Greene. In both incidents, it was determined that you knowingly provided false information to law enforcement investigators while at the scene. Lieutenant Greenes investigation also revealed that you knowingly failed to disclose a personal relationship you were having with a convicted felon. The investigation also revealed that Lieutenant Greenes investigation was reviewed by Lieutenant Vingom who SUSTAINED the following policy and law violations: Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 3 Nevada County MOU General Employees Unit 39, Subsection (B)(6) - Causes for Discipline (SUSTAINED) f.) Dishonesty Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 4 Nevada County Sheriffs Office Policy Manual Lexipol Policy 319.4 General Standards (SUSTAINED) Members shall conduct themselves, whether on- or off-duty, in accordance with the United States and California constitutions and all applicable laws, ordinances, and rules enacted or established pursuant to legal authority. Members shall familiarize themselves with policies and procedures and are responsible for compliance with each. Members should seek clarification and guidance from supervisors in the event of any perceived ambiguity or uncertainty. Discipline may be initiated for any good cause. It is not mandatory that a specific policy or rule violation be cited to sustain discipline. This policy is not intended to cover every possible type of misconduct. Lexipol Policy 319.5.9(p) (SUSTAINED) Any on-or-off duty conduct which any member knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a member of this office, is contrary to good order, efficiency, or morale, or tends to reflect unfavorably upon this office or its members. After reviewing Lt Greenes investigation, I concur with Lt Vingoms sustained finding as outlined above. Additionally, after reviewing the investigation, I also find that you are in violation of: Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 5 ANALYSIS On July 4th, 2023, you were involved in a mutual domestic battery. This incident was investigated by the Grass Valley Police Dept. At that time it was determined that you were told officers that the two of you were engaged and were living together. During that investigation you lied to GVPD Officer Fish about how you sustained your visible injuries. You also lied to officers about your participation in the incident when you told them it was only a verbal argument. You told GVPD Officers your visible injuries were from tripping and falling. It was also noted that you initially identified yourself as an employee of the Sheriffs Office, and you admitted you were under the influence of alcohol. It was also noted that you were heard talking on your phone during the detention, and were recorded telling someone about the incident, and you commented that you were so fired. Your statements were recorded on multiple Grass Valley Police Officers body worn cameras (BWCs). During the Grass Valley Police investigation of the July 4th incident, they learned that a citizen had recorded your altercation on a cell phone, and they obtained a copy of the video recording. In the recording you can been seen walking after your boyfriend on a public sidewalk. As he is walking away from you, he stops and then two of you start arguing again. While he is standing in front of you, you abruptly hit him across his face. He then subsequently grabs you and throws you onto the ground. In watching the video, it was clear the statements you made to the officers regarding how you sustained the injuries to your hands and knees was a lie. It was also very clear that when you told Officer Fish it was only a verbal argument, that too was a lie. In watching the video recording, it was clear that at that moment you were the dominant aggressor. Your recorded comment that evening about being fired and your knowledge about what you had done during the argument provides sufficient motivation for you to lie. On July 4th you had the option of telling the truth, remaining silent, or simply telling the responding officers you did not want to provide a statement. Instead, you chose to knowingly provide false information. As a person who had been a Correctional Officer for over two years, and also having earned a degree in Administration of Justice, you should have known that providing false information is absolutely unacceptable. On July 22nd, 2023, (18 days later) a disturbance at your residence was reported to the Sheriffs Office. You were contacted at your residence and were found inside with an injury to your head and other parts of your body. On the evening of this event, and when questioned later by investigators, you told them that you did not know how you sustained your injuries. You also claimed you didnt not know who caused your injuries. It was later learned that while you were seeking treatment for your injuries, you had sent messages to a coworker naming your boyfriend as the person that was responsible for your injuries. Again, instead of telling the truth, remaining silent, or telling law enforcement officers you did not wish to make a statement, you defaulted to providing a false statement. It is also noted that you were under the influence of alcohol during this incident. Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 6 CONCLUSION , and knowingly provide false information on multiple occasions, is a violation of state law, Sheriffs Office Policy, Nevada County Policies, and the Local 39 MOU. Sheriffs Office employees have always, and will always, be held to a greater standard. This is further evidenced by the strict Sheriffs Office hiring standards and a pre-employment background process, which is not required by other positions located outside the Sheriffs Office. If you had these types of sustained violations in your background, prior to your employment with the Sheriffs Office, you would not have been selected to be a Correctional Officer. Additionally, had you been convicted in a criminal court of domestic violence, you would not be allowed to be in possession of firearms, which is an essential part of your jobs function. I recognize that Sheriffs Office employees do not have to be perfect, but they must strive to be excellent. A Correctional Officers job is a position of respect and trust. All Sheriffs Office employees are held to the highest standards of behavior. Honesty and credibility are crucial to proper performance of your duties. Dishonesty in matters of public trust is intolerable. Your documented and lengthy pattern of deliberate deception, toward coworkers, supervisors, investigators, and outside law enforcement is irrefutable. Dishonesty is not an isolated act; it is more a continuing trait of character. False statements, misrepresentations and omissions regarding official matters are likely to result in harm to public service, the publics trust in law enforcement and irreparable harm to the reputation of the Sheriffs Office and its employees. Notice of Proposed Disciplinary Action, re. IA 2023-003 June 20, 2024 Page 7 RECOMMENDATION: As a result of the investigation and above sustained charges, I am recommending the following discipline to the Sheriff, which I find to be worthy based on all the facts and findings. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT SUPPORTING MATERIALS: The materials upon which this proposed disciplinary action is based include the following documents: Internal Affairs Investigation IA 2023-003 The entire contents of your personnel file Local 39 MOU Nevada County Personnel Code Nevada County Sheriffs Office Corrections Policy Nevada County Sheriffs Office Policy Manual RIGHT TO RESPOND: Officer Aguirre resigned prior to the completion of this document. Sincerely, Shannan Moon Sheriff-Coroner ___________________________________ Mike Walsh Jail Commander / Sheriffs Captain I, Officer Aguirre, without either admitting or denying the allegations contained herein, acknowledge receiving this notice on June___________, 2024. __________________________________ Officer Aguirre Enclosures cc: Human Resources

MEMORANDUM DATE: November 21, 2023 TO: Mr. Cole Bennett FROM: Chief White SUBJECT: NOTICE OF FINDINGS, IA NO. 23-07 The investigation into the above referenced personnel complaint investigation has been completed. A review of the investigation has led to the following classifications for each allegation, based on the preponderance of the evidence standard: ALLEGATION 1. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Bennett, while on-duty, engaged in criminal and/or disgraceful conduct that adversely affected the employee/employer relationship with regards to his possession of a prohibited knife and the concealing and/or discarding of that knife following an officer-involved shooting. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(o) Criminal, dishonest, infamous or disgraceful conduct adversely affecting the employee/employer relationship, whether on- or off-duty. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. - Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. ALLEGATION 2. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Bennett, while on-duty, violated a misdemeanor or felony statute by possessing a concealed knife prohibited by California Penal Code 21310 and department policy. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(z) Violating any misdemeanor or felony statute. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. - Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. Adjudication, IA No. IA23-07 Page 2 ALLEGATION 3. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Bennett, while on-duty, engaged in conduct which any employee knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a member of the Department or which is contrary to good order, efficiency or morale, or which tends to reflect unfavorably upon the Department or its members, related to his possession, concealment and discarding of a prohibited knife following an officer involved shooting. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(aa) Any other on-duty or off-duty conduct which any employee knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a member of the Department or which is contrary to good order, efficiency or morale, or which tends to reflect unfavorably upon the Department or its members. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. 3. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 r. Any act or conduct either during or outside duty hours which is incompatible or inconsistent with City employment or which is conduct unbecoming City employment ALLEGATION 4. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Bennett, while on-duty, failed to promptly report activities on his part to the Department related to his possession of a prohibited knife. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.2(f) Failure of any employee to promptly and fully report activities on their own part or the part of any other employee where such activities may result in criminal prosecution or discipline under this policy. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. ALLEGATION 5. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, and for approximately two to three months prior, Officer Bennett, while on-duty, carried a prohibited knife. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 307.3 Authorized firearms, ammunition and other weapons Adjudication, IA No. IA23-07 Page 3 2. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(m) Any knowing or negligent violation of the provisions of the department manual, operating procedures or other written directive of an authorized supervisor. The Department shall make this manual available to all employees. Employees shall familiarize themselves with this manual and be responsible for compliance with each of the policies contained herein. 3. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. LEVEL OF DISCIPLINE Unable to impose discipline as you are no longer employed with this agency. NOTICE TO EMPLOYEE The above classifications are limited to allegations in which you were the subject. A copy of this memorandum will be placed in your personnel file. You can review the completed investigation by contacting Executive Assistant Mariette Cesar. Additionally, you can make a written response. Any such response must be in writing and submitted to my office within 30 calendar days. ANDREW WHITE Chief of Police

DATE: November 17, 2023 TO: Monterey County Sheriff Tina Nieto 1414 Natividad Road Salinas, CA 93906 FROM: Monterey County District Attorneys Office SUBJECT: Officer Involved Fatality Date of Incident: August 8, 2023 Location of Incident: 404 Hyland Drive, Salinas, CA Deceased: Anthony Tovar Involved Officers: MCSO Detective David Gonzalez & MCSO Deputy Cristian Pantoja DA Case No.: 23-0005 Sheriff Nieto: The District Attorneys Office has completed its investigation and review of the facts surrounding the officer involved shooting that occurred on August 8, 2023. The scope of this review is narrow. It is not to advise concerning best practices for law enforcement in the field, but rather to determine if any officer committed a crime beyond a reasonable doubt. Our review determined the evidence does not show beyond a reasonable doubt the officers in question committed any crime. Specifically, there is insufficient evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt the two officers who fatally shot Anthony Tovar did not have an actual and reasonable belief that Anthony Tovar posed a danger of great bodily injury or death to an officer or civilian when they fatally shot him. FACTS The investigation conducted by the District Attorneys Office included: District Attorney Investigator interviews of the involved officers and civilian witnesses Review of audio and video recordings by law enforcement, including dispatch recordings and 911 audio recordings Review of physical evidence Review of all reports MONTEREY COUNTY OFFICE OF THE DISTRICT ATTORNEY JEANNINE M. PACIONI On August 8, 2023, at around 8:40pm, Anthony Tovar approached a residence and repeatedly knocked on the door. While husband was not present, his wife and two-year old child were home by themselves. Wife did not open the door but became alarmed and contacted husband for assistance. Tovar left before husband returned home. Husband arrived and discussed the events with his wife. He observed Anthony Tovar (25) on his Ring Camera footage and recognized him as a neighbor from across the street. The Ring videos show Tovar knocking on the door at 08:40pm, 08:41pm, and 08:49pm. Husband then went to Tovars address at 407 Hyland Drive and contacted him. Tovar claimed that he had been looking for his dog. Husband left and returned home. Husband estimates that around ten minutes later, Tovar returned to husband and wifes residence. Husband opened the door and stepped outside to speak with Tovar. Tovar pushed passed him and rushed into the house towards wife who was holding her small child. Tovar pulled out a knife. Tovar said that husband had the ability to release Tovars friends from incarceration. Husband begged Tovar to release his family and tried unsuccessfully to take the knife from Tovar. Tovar held a large knife to wifes throat as he forced her, with her child, to the rear bedroom and barricaded all of them inside. Husband frantically called 911 dispatch asking for a law enforcement response at around 9:30pm. MCSO Sergeant Gonzalez, MCSO Deputy Pantoja, MCSO Deputy Ramirez, and MCSO Deputy Perez responded. At 9:33pm, dispatch advised the responding units that the male (Tovar) was inside the residence with a knife and had forced wife and child into the back bedroom at knifepoint. At 9:34pm, Sergeant Gonzalez arrived on scene and was flagged down by husband who told him that a man (Tovar) was inside his residence with a knife and had his wife and child. Tovar had locked the door. Sergeant Gonzalez, Deputy Ramirez, and Deputy Pantoja decided to immediately enter the residence. After entering the residence, they rushed to the locked bedroom door and verbally announced Sheriffs Department. Sergeant Gonzalez kicked the door multiple times and was able to get it open between 12 and 18 inches. Deputy Pantoja was to his left. Deputies yelled repeatedly for Tovar to Open the door! Tovar had placed a dresser in front of the door to act as a barricade. Sergeant Gonzalez looked in the room and saw wife and child crying on the floor of the bedroom. He also saw wife embracing her child. He saw Tovar facing them with a large knife in his right hand. The knife was over twelve inches in length. Tovar was about five feet from the wife and child while Sergeant Gonzalez was five feet away from Tovar. Sergeant Gonzalez pointed his handgun at Tovar and yelled several commands at Tovar to drop the knife! Tovar refused, waived his hand in a go-away motion, and turned his attention back to wife and child. Sergeant Gonzalez estimated the knife to be around 3 feet away from wife and child. Sergeant Gonzalez fired one shot at Tovar hitting him in the torso. Deputy Pantoja fired one shot and Sergeant Gonzalez fired two more shots. Tovar fell to the ground. The knife was removed from his hand, he was handcuffed, first aid was administered, and medical personnel were dispatched. Tovar was pronounced dead on scene. LEGAL STANDARDS The California District Attorneys Association charge filing standard directs prosecutors to assess whether the evidence would warrant conviction by a jury, which requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt. The sole purpose of this review is to determine whether any officer was criminally responsible for the death of Anthony Tovar. On August 19, 2019, Governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill 392 into law, which changed the law governing the use of deadly force by police officers and went into effect on January 1, 2020. Under PC 835a(c)(1), a peace officer is justified in using deadly force upon another person only when the officer reasonably believes, based on the totality of circumstances, that such force is necessary . . . to defend against an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or to another person. It also allows for the use of deadly force, to apprehend a fleeing person for any felony that threatened or resulted in death or serious bodily injury, if the officer reasonably believes that the person will cause death or serious bodily injury to another unless immediately apprehended. Where feasible, a peace officer shall, prior to the use of force, make reasonable efforts to identify themselves as a peace officer and to warn that deadly force may be used, unless the officer has objectively reasonable grounds to believe the person is aware of those facts. A threat of death or serious bodily injury is imminent when, based on the totality of the circumstances, a reasonable officer in the same situation would believe that a person has the present ability, opportunity, and apparent intent to immediately cause death or serious bodily injury to the peace officer or another person. (Id. at subsection (e)(2).) The statute states that totality of the circumstances means all facts known to the peace officer at the time, including the conduct of the officer and the subject leading up to the use of deadly force. (Id. at subsection (e)(3).) Under the law, any personincluding a police officercan use deadly force in self-defense or in defense of others if the person reasonably believes the immediate use of deadly force is necessary to defend against an imminent danger of great bodily injury or death. The danger does not need to exist as long as the person reasonably believes the danger exists. Further, a person acting in self-defense or defense of others is not required to retreat. The person is entitled to stand his or her ground or even, if reasonable, to pursue an assailant until the danger of death or bodily injury has passed. This is so even if safety could have been achieved by retreating. Police officers can lawfully use deadly force even if from 20/20 hindsight other feasible options may have existed. The situation must be viewed from the perspective of a reasonable officer at the scene. Officers are forced to make split-second judgmentsin circumstances that are tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolvingabout the amount of force that is necessary in a particular situation. When a person has a genuine belief using force in self-defense, or defense of others, is immediately necessary, a person is not guilty of a homicide unless the belief in self-defense, or defense of others, was unreasonable at the time. CONCLUSION There is no basis to conclude that Sergeant Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja had anything but a genuine belief that deadly force was immediately necessary. Because Tovar kidnapped the mother and her two-year-old child at knifepoint, imprisoned them in their rear bedroom behind a barricaded closed door, displayed a deadly weapon, failed to follow the lawful commands of deputies, and given the totality of these unpredictable and extremely dangerous circumstances, the deputies could reasonably believe Tovar was an imminent threat to the lives of his captors. Therefore, insufficient evidence exists to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Sergeant Gonzalez or Deputy Pantoja committed any crime. The role of the District Attorney is not to evaluate the efficacy of departmental tactics or training, nor of course to consider issues of civil liability. Those processes may have the goal of identifying areas for improvement in future similar encounters; they may take advantage of the benefit of hindsight and information not known to the involved peace officers. The role of the District Attorney in deciding whether to charge officers with a crime requires judging their conduct and actions from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene at the time of the incident with the information available in a rapidly evolving high- stress encounter. Consequently, having found there is insufficient evidence to prove any crime beyond a reasonable doubt, no further action by this office is contemplated or warranted. Ryan J. McGuirk Chief Investigator Case No.: MCDA 23-0005 Date: 08/30/2023 Supplement Report No.: DAI Rpt. 001 Re: Anthony Tovar / Monterey County Sheriffs Office OIS Page 1 of 6 Investigator: K. Hunsaker By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 1 of 6 MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION DECEDENT Name: Anthony Tovar DOB: 07/22/1998 Physical Description: HMA, 53, 130 lbs., Blk/Blk Home Address: 18807 Moro Road, Salinas, CA 93907 Driver License/CII CA Y8169050 / A37472173 MCSO Case FG2304178 MCSO Coroner Case 2023-00685 Santa Cruz County Coroner Case 23-06441 VICTIM Name: Victim 1 VICTIM Name: Victim 2 VICTIM Name: Victim 3 INVOLVED SERGEANT Name: David Gonzalez Agency: Monterey County Sheriffs Office INVOLVED DEPUTY Name: Cristian Pantoja Agency: Monterey County Sheriffs Office MENTIONED Name: Rebeka Okaneku, Monterey County Sheriffs Office Forensic Evidence Technician Address: 1414 Natividad Rd., Salinas, CA Phone : 831-755-3700 SYNOPSIS: On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Dr. in Salinas. Decedent Anthony Tovar forced his way into the residence, grabbed a female adult and placed a knife to her neck while the adult female was holding her 2-year-old daughter. After Tovar MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI Rpt. 001 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 2 of 6 barricaded himself and the two victims inside a bedroom, Monterey County Sheriffs Office personnel breached the door and discharged their firearms fatally striking Tovar. NARRATIVE: On 08/08/2023 at approximately 2220 hours, I was alerted that an OIS had occurred at 404 Hyland Dr. in Salinas and I was requested to respond to the scene by District Attorney Investigative Captain (DAIC) J. Ferreria. I arrived on scene at approximately 2310 hours. I was designated the Lead Investigator by DAIC Ferreria. I was assisted by District Attorney Investigators (DAI) Smith, Gomez, and Williams. It should be noted that DAIC Ferreria and DAI Williams left the scene to photograph Monterey County Sheriffs Office (MCSO) personnel involved in the shooting and they conducted a round count of the associated OIS weapons. DAI Smith and I were then directed to obtain a statement from the reporting party, Victim 1. It should be noted that Victim 1 was seated in an MCSO patrol vehicle prior to the interview. It should also be noted that I audio- recorded the interview with Victim 1 with my department-issued digital recorder (Item KH 1). The following is a summary of the interview with Victim 1. SUMMARY OF INTERVIEW WITH VICTIM 1: After exiting the patrol vehicle, DAI Smith and I identified ourselves to Victim 1 and he agreed to speak with us. Victim 1 confirmed he lived at 404 Hyland Dr. with his wife, Victim 2, and their two-year-old daughter, Victim 3. Victim 1 provided verbal consent to search the home regarding our investigation. Victim 1 stated a male adult, later identified as Decedent Tovar, entered his home, proceeded into the kitchen area of the home where he grabbed Victim 2 and Victim 3 and took them into a rear bedroom of the residence utilized by Victim 3. Victim 1 stated Tovar first approached the residence at approximately 2030 hours on 08/08/2023. Victim 1 was not present at the residence but was informed that Tovar was knocking aggressively on the front door and side door of the residence while Victim 2 was inside the residence with Victim 3. Victim 2 did not open the doors. After arriving at the home, Victim 1 did MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI Rpt. 001 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 3 of 6 not see Tovar. However, Victim 1 accessed his Ring camera which was mounted next to the residences front door. After he reviewed the Ring cameras video to see who had been knocking the residences front door earlier on 08/08/2023, Victim 1 said, It seemed like the neighbor. Victim 1 stated he went across the street to attempt to discover why Tovar had been knocking on the door. Victim 1 stated he observed Tovar come around the side of a pink residence (407 A Hyland Dr.) behind 407 Hyland Dr. According to Victim 1, Tovar stated he had been looking for his dog at Victim 1s residence earlier in the evening. Victim 1 and Tovar then parted ways. Victim 1 stated Tovar returned to 404 Hyland Dr. and knocked on the front door about 10 minutes after his first encounter with Tovar. Victim 1 opened the door and noted Tovar was acting kind of weird because he wanted to step inside the house. Victim 1 stated he told Tovar they could speak outside the residence. However, Tovar went around Victim 1, entered the residence through the open front door, and approached Victim 2 in the kitchen area of the residence. Victim 2 was holding Victim 3. After grabbing Victim 2 and Victim 3, Tovar brandished a knife. Victim 1 stated that Tovar made several comments including, you have to help me, because I have some friends in prison, and you have power to get them out. Victim 1 stated he pleaded with Tovar to release Victim 2 and Victim 3 and to leave the residence. Victim 1 stated he began struggling with Tovar and unsuccessfully attempted to grab of the knife. Tovar then forced Victim 2 and Victim 3 into the residences rear bedroom and locked the door leaving Victim 1 outside the bedroom. Victim 1 then called law enforcement. Victim 1 confirmed Tovar had the knife prior to entering the residence. Victim 1 stated Tovar made additional comments about friends in prison and that Victim 1 had the power to release these individuals from incarceration. Victim 1 stated he didnt know Tovar but believed Tovar was associated with the pink residence behind 407 Hyland Dr. Victim 1 stated after he called law enforcement, he continued to plead with Tovar to release his family and to not hurt them. Victim 1 exited the residence and spoke with law enforcement when MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI Rpt. 001 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 4 of 6 they arrived. When law enforcement entered his residence, Victim 1 followed but was ordered to leave the residence. Victim 1 confirmed he was inside the home when he heard gunshots. Victim 1 stated he did not hear anything prior to the gunshots. Victim 1 stated Tovar spoke mostly to Victim 1 after entering the home in the kitchen area, mainly concerning the release of Tovars incarcerated friends. Victim 1 stated he observed Tovar grab Victim 2 around her shoulders and Tovar had the knife behind Victim 2. Victim 1 stated when Tovar first knocked on the residences front door, Victim 2 contacted Victim 1 to inform him of the situation. Victim 1 arrived at the residence approximately 10 minutes later and accessed his Ring camera system. Victim 1 stated he attempted to speak with Tovar through his Ring camera system but the battery was low and he was unable to communicate with Tovar. DAI Smith and I had no additional questions for Victim 1 and ended the interview at approximately 2335 hours. NARRATIVE: After the interview with Victim 1 was concluded, DAI Smith and I remained at the scene of the OIS. MCSO Forensic Evidence Technician (FET) R. Okaneku arrived and began processing the crime scene. DAI Smith accompanied FET Okaneku while FET Okaneku processed the crime scene. DAI Smith also took digital photographs of the scene. I remained on scene with DAI Smith and FET Okaneku (See reports from FET Okaneku and DAI Smith). I left the scene of the OIS at approximately 0430 hours on 08/09/2023. On 08/09/2023, I assisted DAI Smith with processing several evidence items recovered from the OIS scene (See DAI Smiths report). Later on 08/09/2023, DAI Gomez and I contacted Victim 2 at 17105 El Rancho Way in Salinas. It should be noted that Victim 2 spoke Spanish only. DAI Gomez, who is a certified Spanish speaker with Monterey County, conducted the interview (See DAI Gomezs report). During the course of the interview with Victim 2, DAI Gomez and I were MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI Rpt. 001 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 5 of 6 informed Tovar grabbed Victim 2s pants and attempted to pull them down while Tovar held her inside the bedroom at 404 Hyland Dr. causing her underwear to rip. Victim 2 provided the grey underwear to DAI Gomez. I took two digital photographs (Item KH 3) of the grey underwear before DAI Gomez collected them as evidence (Item LG 01). Item LG 01 was later booked into evidence at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office. DAI Gomez and I were also informed Tovars grey sweatshirt/jacket had not been removed from 404 Hyland Dr. DAI Gomez and I accompanied Victim 1 to 404 Hyland Dr. and I recovered the grey sweatshirt/jacket (Item KH 2) which was located on top of the bed in the rear bedroom where the OIS occurred. I also took three digital photographs of the grey sweatshirt/jacket before I collected the item (Item KH 4). Item KH 2 was later booked into evidence at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office. Inv. R. Smith Page 2 of 4 SYNOPSIS: On 08/08/2023, an Officer-Involved Shooting (OIS) occurred at 404 Hyland Drive in Salinas. Monterey County Sheriffs Office (MCSO) Deputies responded to a call of a man with a knife. Anthony Tovar had forcibly taken a mother and her two-year-old child at knife point into a bedroom and barricaded the door. MCSO Deputies breached the bedroom and observed Tovar with a knife. The deputies discharged their firearms striking Tovar. Tovar did not survive. NARRATIVE: On 08/08/2023 at 2219 hours, I received a request to respond to an OIS that had occurred on the 400 block of Hyland Drive in Salinas, CA. I arrived at the scene at approximately 2236 hours. I contacted Chief District Attorney Investigator, Ryan McGuirk, and District Attorney Investigative Captain, John Ferreria, who directed District Attorney Investigator (DAI), Hunsaker, and I to interview the Reporting Party (RP), Jose De Jesus Valdivia. During the interview, Valdivia gave us verbal consent to enter and search his residence located at 404 Hyland Drive. Please refer to DAI Hunsakers report for a summary of Valdivias interview. Once we obtained consent to enter Valdivias home, DAI Hunsaker and I were tasked with locating and documenting evidence within the residence. We were notified that MCSOs Forensic Evidence Technician (FET), Rebeka Okaneku, was enroute and we would be assisting in processing the scene. Once FET Okaneku arrived, I was tasked with taking digital photographs of the scene which included the residence at 404 Hyland Drive, the evidence located within the residence, and photos of the decedent. After the photographs were taken, we marked each evidence item with yellow numbered placards. I took additional photographs of the evidence items with the placards. I stood by as FET Okaneku took multiple scans of the residence at 404 Hyland Drive. Once the MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT. 002 By: D.A. Inv. R. Smith Page 3 of 4 scans were completed, I collected the following evidence from the residence: Item RS-001, 9mm shell casing WMA P (Placard 3) Item RS-002, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 4) Item RS-003, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 5) Item RS-004, Knife w/ black handle, approximately 300 mm in length (Placard 6) Item RS-005, 9mm shell casing WIN 9mm Luger (Placard 7) It should be noted that placards 1 and 2 were placed next to black latex gloves that were found at the scene. The items were photographed, but the gloves were not taken as evidence. The coroner deputy arrived on scene to examine and prepare the decedents body for transport. When the coroner deputy moved the decedents body and searched his pants pockets, an iPhone, a Mercedes car key, and a DeWalt box cutter were found in the pockets. When the coroner deputy moved the decedents legs a spent projectile (bullet) was found that had been under the decedents boots. I took photographs and collected the items that were found in the decedents pockets as well as the mushroomed projectile (bullet). They were labeled as the following evidence items: Item RS-006, Black iPhone w/ gray case Item RS-007, Mercedes car key w/ gray fob attached. Item RS-008, DeWalt box cutter (yellow/black) Item RS-009, Spent Projectile (mushroomed) The evidence items were labeled, packaged, and placed in an evidence locker at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office for storage. Two hundred and eleven photographs were taken of the scene. I uploaded the photographs into Evidence.com and labeled the folder as evidence item RS-010. Three additional photographs were taken of evidence item RS-004 (Knife) once I was at the office. I photographed the knife alongside a scale to show the length of the knife and the blade. I uploaded those photographs to Evidence.com as item RS-011. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT. 002 By: D.A. Inv. R. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 1 of 11 MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION DECEDENT Name: Anthony Tovar DOB: 07/22/1998 Physical Description: HMA, 53, 130 lbs., Blk/Blk Home Address: 18807 Moro Road, Salinas, CA 93907 Driver License/CII CA Y8169050 / A37472173 MCSO Case FG2304178 Santa Cruz County Coroner Case 23006441 VICTIM Name: Victim 1 VICTIM Name: Victim 2 VICTIM Name: Victim 3 INVOLVED SERGEANT Name: David Gonzalez Agency: Monterey County Sheriff INVOLVED DEPUTY Name: Cristian Pantoja Agency: Monterey County Sheriff NARRATIVE: On August 8, 2023, at approximately 2300 hours, I, Monterey County District Attorney Investigator (DAI) Leo GÃ³mez , arrived at the crime scene at Captain John Ferrerias request. I contacted Victim 1 at his parents home, which was located at 17105 El Rancho Way, Salinas CA 93907. Victim 1 signed a consent form (Item LG05) to search his residence. I signed this document as a Witness, and I forwarded it to DAI Kris Hunsaker. Victim 1 also delivered to me four digital videos (Item LG02) from his Ring camera that was installed at the front door of his residence. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 2 of 11 These videos showed Decedent Tovar and his dog outside the victims front door. I also delivered this evidence to DAI Hunsaker. Conversations with Tovars relatives: On August 9, 2023, at approximately 1104 hours, DAI Rachel Maldonado and I visited Tovars home and we spoke to a number of Tovars family members who were gathered there praying. Among the large group were Tovars parents, his sister and her husband. I spoke to these persons in Spanish and I gathered additional information about Tovars mental history and whereabouts the day before. One of the Tovars sisters (NoemÃ­) spoke both English and Spanish. I recorded our conversation using a digital device and I transferred the audio file to Evidence.com (Item LG03). I also photographed the Tovars medication and a knife we found at the home, which resembled the knife Tovar used to kidnap the victims. The following is a synopsis of my conversation with Tovars relatives. For complete details, please refer to the audio file. The names of the family members I spoke to were Berta Murillo and Ernesto Tovar (Tovars parents), NoemÃ­ Tovar (Tovars sister) and Jorge (NoemÃ­ Tovars husband.) Mental Illness: Tovars parents stated that Tovar had lived with them through his whole life and was unemployed at the time of the officer-involved shooting (OIS). Tovar attended North Monterey County High School for approximately two years but did not graduate. There was consensus among the relatives that Tovar suffered from mental illness and was taking some medications but the length of his illness, depending on who spoke, was either three, four or ten years. Tovars parents did not exactly know what Tovars diagnosis was, but NoemÃ­ indicated that he suffered from schizophrenia. Ernesto and Berta stated that Tovar was being treated at Natividad Hospital for mental illness and, sometime in the past, he had been housed at psychiatric facilities in Monterey and Santa Cruz counties. The Santa Cruz County stay lasted approximately one week and occurred sometime in 2021. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 3 of 11 Bertha stated that Tovars illness began in adulthood and manifested with hallucinations. Bertha described Tovar talking to invisible persons. Bertha also stated that Tovar didnt sleep and spent all night walking around their home. The relatives stated that Tovar was often profane and verbally abusive towards his parents but he was never violent at home. The relatives also stated that Tovar had been arrested multiple times for various reasons, including mental illness, bad temper, and for entering a neighbors home without permission. Tovars relatives did not know that neighbors name, but they indicated that the neighbor came to Tovars home and told his parents that he would shoot Tovar with a gun if he ever entered his home again. Bertha stated that on one occasion, Tovar called her from the Monterey County Jail and stated that he could see her and Ernesto inside the jail with him. NoemÃ­ and Jorge stated that they knew Tovar better than anyone else because Tovar often visited them at their home (1157 Ranchero Drive, Salinas CA 93905) and he spent a lot of time with them. They also stated that Tovar s ex-girlfriend, whose first name was Destiny, was one of their neighbors on Ranchero Drive. Illicit drugs use: NoemÃ­, Bertha, Ernesto and Jorge stated that Tovar used illicit drugs, including cannabis and methamphetamine, which he obtained from friends. They also stated that Tovars mental illness intensified with drug use. NoemÃ­ stated that Tovar began using drugs after he completed probation. NoemÃ­ also stated that Tovar told her that he was anxious about finishing probation, so he could start using cannabis. Tovars whereabouts preceding the OIS: Jorge stated that one or two days before the OIS, around 0400 hours, Tovar went to Destinys home and climbed on the roof without permission. Jorge learned about this incident from NoemÃ­, who was informed by Destinys father, who saw him on the roof but did not call law enforcement. Destinys father spoke to Jorge about that incident and he was upset. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 4 of 11 On the date of the OIS, Tovar visited NoemÃ­ at her home and she became afraid of him because he was acting up. NoemÃ­ was unable to explain what she meant by acting up, but she mentioned that Tovar was moving and touching his face. Her description seemed to describe the behavior of someone under the influence of a stimulant. NoemÃ­ also stated that Tovar was out of control because he had broken up with Destiny. Tovar was still with NoemÃ­ when Jorge got home from work at approximately 1900 hours, although he was outside the home in his car, which he had driven to NoemÃ­s home. Jorge described that when he arrived home, Tovar was OK but lacked concentration, which he attributed to the roof climbing incident at Destinys home. Jorge told Tovar that he did not want him at his home anymore because of the trespassing incident at Destinys home. NoemÃ­ cried (presumably at the prospect of not having Tovar visit her home again) and Tovar apologized for his behavior and stated that he would not bother Destiny anymore. Tovar left NoemÃ­ and Jorges home crying, in his vehicle, after NoemÃ­ also told him that she didnt want him at her home due to the ongoing drama with Destiny. She also told him that she feared he would do something to her or her children when Jorge wasnt home. NoemÃ­ explained that she feared Tovar because he did not take his medication and he was abusive to her parents. Tovars relatives did not know when Tovar had last slept or for how long before the OIS, but they believed that he had been awake for 24 or 48 hours since the roof climbing incident at Destinys home. Berta stated that sometime during the evening, prior to the OIS, she saw Tovar standing outside her home, talking to a man. The man told Tovar in Spanish, I saw you in the cameras and what were you doing there? Tovar told the man, I went to get the dog. The dog went over there and I went to get him. Tovars relatives described Tovars dog as a white Chihuahua. Ernesto also heard the conversation between Tovar and the man, and he provided a statement that substantiated MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 5 of 11 Berthas narrative. Sometime thereafter, Bertha noticed police vehicles near her home and she went outside and called Tovar but he was nowhere to be seen. Ernesto stated that after speaking to the man, Tovar entered his home through a rear door and went to the kitchen. Berta and Ernesto didnt know where Tovar went thereafter he was in the kitchen. Tovars medications: Inside Tovars home, on a kitchen shelf, I observed multiple medication containers, three of which had labels from the CVS pharmacy located at 110 Laurel Drive, Salinas, CA 93906. The labels indicated that the medications were prescribed to Tovar by doctors K. Routiher or M. Garuba. The label on the first container was dated June 10, 2023, and read 15 mg Mirtazapine tablet and Take 1 tablet by mouth every day at bedtime. The prescription was for 30 tablets and the container held 29 tables labeled 0 8 A which I verified on the drugs.com website as the imprint for Mirtazapine, an antidepressant. The following two images are photographs of this medication: The label on the second container, dated October 21, 2021, indicated a prescription for 60 Buspirone Hydrochloride 15 mg pills. The label read, 1 tab by mouth twice daily. The container held 57 intact tables labeled 5 5 5 TV 1003 and four half- tablets of the same medicine. The drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the container label. The image below is a photograph of this medication: The label on the third container, dated July 20, 2022, indicated a prescription for 30 Olanzapine 5 mg tablets. The label read, take 1 tablet every day at bedtime. The container held 26 intact tables labeled CL 40. The drugs.com website indicated that the imprint on the pills matched the container label. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 6 of 11 The large number of tablets found in each container, coupled with the date of the prescriptions and instructions, seemed to corroborate NoemÃ­s statement about Tovar not taking his medications. The image below is a photograph of this knife: MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 7 of 11 Conversation with Victim 2: On August 9, 2023, at approximately 1423 hours, DAI Hunsaker and I spoke with Victim 2 at her father-in-laws home. Present during our conversation was her husband, Victim 1. I recorded our conversation using a digital device (Item LG04) and I transferred the audio file to Evidence.com. Victim 2 stated that she resided at her home with her daughter (Victim 3) and her husband. On the date of the OIS she was at home with her daughter. Victim 1 arrived home from work at approximately 1500 hours to eat, and he returned to work at approximately 1600 hours. At approximately 2030 hours, someone knocked on her front door, which was closed but unlocked. Victim 2 believed that the person at the door was her husband, so she approached the door, looked through the door glass, and noticed that the person outside was not her husband, but a young man (Tovar) with a small dog. Tovar was wearing a hoodie, sweatpants and a gray or black item over his face. Tovar made eye contact with Victim 2, hand signaled for her to open the door and remained there for five or ten minutes. Victim 2 panicked and did not open the door. Victim 2 took her daughter to her master bedroom, stayed there some time, called Victim 1 and told him that a stranger was knocking at the front door. Victim 1 told Victim 2 that he was coming home and would arrive in ten minutes. Tovar stopped knocking on the front door for approximately three minutes and began knocking on the side door that was located on the homes north side, between the kitchen and Victim 3s room. This door led from the kitchen to the driveway. Victim 2 called Victim 1 a second time and he tried to talk to Tovar via their front door camera, but the device was not working. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that he was driving home and would be there soon. When he arrived, Victim 1 told Victim 2 that, based on what he saw through the MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 8 of 11 front door camera, he believed Tovar was one of their neighbors. Victim 1 also told Victim 2 that he was going to go talk to that neighbor (Tovar) to see what he needed or wanted. Victim 1 walked to Tovars home, which was located in an alley perpendicular to the victims street. After speaking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned home and told Victim 2 that Tovar had gone to their home looking for a dog. After talking to Tovar, Victim 1 returned to his residence, and approximately ten minutes later, Tovar returned to the porch of the victims residence, while Victim 1 was taking his work clothes off to get in the shower. Victim 1 went outside and talked to Tovar, leaving his front door ajar. Tovar ran inside the victims residence, stood approximately 10 feet away from the front door and produced a knife, while Victim 1 stood at the door. When Tovar entered the home, Victim 2 was in the kitchen and her daughter was sitting at the kitchen counter, close to the dining room. Tovar told Victim 1 to close the front door and made incoherent statements, demanding that Victim 1 help him get his family members and his daughter out of prison. Victim 1 told Tovar to go outside with him and let his wife and daughter go. At some point, Tovar moved closer to Victim 1 (farther away from the child), so Victim 2 took advantage of this opportunity to run and pick up Victim 3 from the counter area. She held the child in her arms and brought her to the kitchen, behind the counter, near the stove, and away from Tovar. Victim 2 grabbed her cellular telephone to call 911 but Tovar told her not to call the police. While Tovar was making his incoherent demands, Victim 2 attempted to escape with her daughter through the aforementioned kitchen side door. Victim 2 held the child with her left arm against her chest and handled the door knob with her right hand, but she was unable to open it. When Victim 2 was facing the side door and struggling to open it, Tovar approached her, stood behind her, and prevented her escape by wrapping his left arm across her chest and putting his MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.004 By: D.A. Inv. Leo GÃ³mez 40333 Page 9 of 11 knife, with his right hand, against the right side of her neck. Victim 2 felt the blade against her skin. I asked Victim 2 if she could re-enact this frightening event and she demonstrated Tovars actions by standing behind Victim 1, wrapping her left arm across his chest and placing her right hand against the right side of his neck. When Tovar held Victim 2 and her daughter hostage in the kitchen, Victim 1 had his cellphone in his hands, and Tovar told him not to call the police. Tovar then turned Victim 2 and her daughter around 180 degrees, away from the side door and made them face the kitchen refrigerator. Tovar then turned Victim 2 and her daughter ninety degrees to the left of the refrigerator and pushed them with force, against their will away from the kitchen, towards the childs bedroom, which was located to the east of the kitchen, down a short and narrow hallway. Tovar kidnapped the Victim2 and Victim 3, closed the childs bedroom door behind him and also closed the bedrooms window curtain. Tovar ordered Victim 2 to sit at the foot of the bed, which she did, as she held her daughter close to her chest with both arms. Tovar began pacing along a dresser that was located to the right of the bedroom door, along the bedrooms west wall. Tovar then handed Victim 2 his cellular telephone and told her to dial Victim 1s number. Victim 2 complied and handed the phone back to Tovar, who continued walking around the room. Victim 2 did not know if Tovar was able to talk to Victim 1, but eventually Tovar placed his phone on a dresser and told Victim 2 that nothing was going to happen to her or her daughter. Tovar pulled all the dresser drawers out, looking for a gun and he asked Victim 2 if there was a gun in her house. Victim 2 told him that there were no guns at her home. Sometime thereafter, Victim 2 and Tovar heard sirens, and Tovar told her in Spanish, I told your husband not to call the police, now all of us are going to get fucked. Tovar grabbed the leggings and pulled them down with force from the waist area two or three times. While describing this horrible ordeal, Victim 2 used her hands to re-enact her and Tovars actions. The deputies who rescued Victim 2 arrived at the barricaded bedroom door when Victim 2 was on the floor, holding her daughter, with Tovar standing above them with his knife. Victim 2 heard the rescuing deputies give commands to Tovar before they entered the bedroom but she did not understand what they said because she did not speak English. When the rescuing deputies forced the bedroom door open, Victim 2 was still on the floor holding her daughter. Decedent Anthony Tovar forced his way into the residence, grabbed a female adult and placed a knife to her neck while the adult female was holding her 2-year-old daughter. After Tovar MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 2 of 10 barricaded himself and the two victims inside a bedroom, Monterey County Sheriffs Office personnel breached the door and discharged their firearms fatally striking Tovar. NARRATIVE: On 08/11/2023 at approximately 0940 hours, DAI Torres and I conducted an interview with MCSO Acting Sergeant/Detective David Gonzalez who was involved in the OIS. The interview was conducted at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office in Salinas. Also in attendance was Sgt. Gonzalezs legal counsel, Terry Leoni. It should be noted that I audio-recorded the interview with Sgt. Gonzalez with my department-issued digital recorder (Item KH 5). The following is a summary of my interview with Sgt. Gonzalez. SUMMARY OF INTERVIEW WITH MCSO SERGEANT DAVID GONZALEZ: I confirmed with Sgt. Gonzalez that he had not been ordered, coerced, or compelled to be present for the interview and he had spoken with his attorney prior to the interview. I also informed Sgt. Gonzalez he could end the interview at any point and request any needed breaks. Two breaks were taken and the audio recording was paused during each break. I obtained the following information about Sgt. Gonzalez to describe in detail the incident that occurred on 08/08/2023 at 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was near the west end of Boronda Rd. near Hwy. 183 prior to the OIS. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was informed by dispatch that a male subject had entered a residence with a knife. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he made sure the responding deputies were using their emergency lights and sirens enroute to Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch he was near Hyland Dr. and stated he had not activated his emergency lights and sirens to respond. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he was going to stage in the area when he was advised the male subject had a knife and was with the reporting partys (RP) wife and child. Sgt. Gonzales stated he thought this situation was a hostage/rescue kind of ordeal. Sgt. Gonzalez arrived at El Rancho Way and Hyland Dr. and was approached by the RP (Victim 1). Sgt. Gonzalez advised dispatch of his contact with the RP and that the RP had informed Sgt. Gonzalez the suspect was in a rear bedroom with a knife along with the RPs wife and child. Sgt. Gonzalez observed another deputy behind him and told the deputy, Lets go. Were going to make entry into the house. Sgt. Gonzalez entered the residence at 404 Hyland Dr. and was told by the RP the suspect was in the back room and gave permission for Sgt. Gonzalez to kick down the interior bedroom door. Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door once and observed the door had been barricaded by a heavy object. Sgt. Gonzalez stated when he noticed the barricade, That kind of like triggered in me like a different feeling. Like, this is serious and there is a lot of truth to what this guys saying that theres going to be, were going to open the door and were going to be faced with some kind of scenario. Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door harder a second time near the door handle breaking the door panel. Sgt. Gonzalez was able to open the bedroom door approximately 1 1 Â½ feet to look inside the bedroom. When Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the bedroom door, Deputy Cristian Pantoja was MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 5 of 10 on Sgt. Gonzalezs left side while Deputy Josue Ramirez was behind Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez looked into the bedroom and saw a lady and child, later identified as Victim 2 and Victim 3 respectively, sitting on the floor of the bedroom in the northeast corner. Victim 2 was crying and holding Victim 3. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he observed the suspect, later identified as Decedent Tovar, standing approximately five feet away from the female and child. Tovar was facing toward Sgt. Gonzalez but was holding and pointing a knife at the female and child. It was then requested to take a break in the interview. After the break, Sgt. Gonzalez continued with his statement. Sgt. Gonzalez described the bedroom as a small room. After kicking the bedroom door, Tovar was looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja. Sgt. Gonzalez saw the knife in Tovars hand which Sgt. Gonzalez described as a kitchen knife, 9 inches, he was holding it by the handle, pointing it at the lady and the child. Sgt. Gonzalez gave verbal commands to Tovar to drop the knife. Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning his gaze towards the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez then fired one round at Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez said he had previously drawn his pistol upon entering the home and his pistol was kept at low ready until he encountered Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez recognized the object blocking the bedroom door as a clothes dresser approximately 3 4 feet tall and the dresser did not allow the door to be fully opened. Sgt. Gonzalez also observed a closet behind Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, What was going through my head at that point was if he gets an opportunity, and he lunges at them with the knife, was that he was going to harm the child or the lady, and if he came at us, I would get stabbed or my partner would get stabbed. And so as soon as he turned to look at the lady, thats when I fired my first shot. Sgt. Gonzalez said the shot struck Tovar in the front torso. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar returned to an aggressive stance and Tovar continued to hold the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez ordered Tovar to drop the knife and heard Deputy Pantoja also order Tovar to drop the knife. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 6 of 10 Sgt. Gonzalez described Tovar as 5 6 to 5 8 with short hair and thin build. After the first shot, Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar again looked at Sgt. Gonzalez before returning his gaze toward the female in the room. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he then fired three additional rounds striking Tovar at least twice. Sgt. Gonzalez noticed a spent shell casing in the air and deduced Deputy Pantoja fired his pistol as well. After being struck, Tovar fell to the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez heard someone state that Tovar still had the knife. Another deputy removed the knife from Tovar and Sgt. Gonzalez removed the female and child from the room. Sgt. Gonzalez turned over the female and child to Deputy Perez and Sgt. Gonzalez returned to the bedroom where he observed the knife was on the floor between Tovar and the females location prior to her removal from the room. Sgt. Gonzalez provided his handcuffs to Deputy Ramirez who handcuffed Tovar. First aid was then administered to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez cleared the remainder of the home and cleared medical personnel to enter the residence to continue to administer first aid to Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez directed Deputy Perez to separate the female and the RP into separate vehicles. Sgt. Gonzalez assisted in directing the set up of the crime scene and making the appropriate notifications of the OIS to dispatch. Sgt. Gonzalez directed photographs be taken of the crime scene and the victims. Sgt. Gonzalez then returned to MCSO. Sgt. Gonzalez said the RP indicated Tovar was a neighbor and Sgt. Gonzalez could not state if he knew the suspect by sight from any previous encounters. When I asked, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did announce Sheriffs Office after entering the residence. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not attempt to force the door open further after kicking the door the second time as he and Deputy Pantoja were able to see Tovar through the established opening. Sgt. Gonzalez confirmed Tovar held the knife in his right hand. Sgt. Gonzalez was not given a description of Tovar prior to encountering Tovar. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he ordered Tovar to drop the knife 3 4 times. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 7 of 10 Sgt. Gonzalez did not believe he had any additional options available regarding his use of force given the circumstances of the call. Sgt. Gonzalez stated, At that point with what we were addressing, we were presented with a deadly force situation where there was no time to react for a Taser because a Taser could be ineffective. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar appeared to be unaffected by the first gunshot. Sgt. Gonzalez said, In my mind, there was no other option. Sgt. Gonzalez explained the use of a Taser had several drawbacks including agitating Tovar causing Tovar to lunge at Sgt. Gonzalez or the female or child. DAI Torres asked Sgt. Gonzales what was going through his mind when he fired the second volley. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar was still looking for a target because the knife was, like hes ready to go, hes looking to see, he looked at me and then he looked at the lady and thats kind of where, and the knife was so close to them where it would take one step, one half second, and he could have injured like whether its fatally or not fatally, and thats kind of where I thought that he was going to take action with the knife. Sgt. Gonzalez clarified take action to mean stabbing the victims. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he constantly addressed Tovar and did not give commands to the other deputies inside the residence. Sgt. Gonzalez also clarified that when Tovar looked at Sgt. Gonzalez, Tovar was scanning for an option to attack and that was the basis for Sgt. Gonzalezs first shot. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the distance between himself and Tovar to be approximately five feet and Tovar was also approximately five feet away from the female and child who were on the floor. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar was standing, holding the knife while scanning and looked like he was thinking about what he was going to do. So if he had lunged at the lady, in my head, I thought we would not be able to shoot because she would be part of the backdrop. I didnt want to give him that opportunity. Whereas if he had lunged at us, we would still have a clear shot. Sgt. Gonzalez stated other than his commands to Tovar to drop the knife, he did not have time to attempt any other forms of de-escalation. Additionally, Sgt. Gonzalez stated he did not have time to discuss the use of less than lethal options prior to entering the residence. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 8 of 10 Sgt. Gonzalez estimated 1 2 minutes elapsed from the time he entered the residence until the shots were fired. Sgt. Gonzalez stated Tovar did not say anything during the encounter. Sgt. Gonzalez stated had there been ample time to retrieve the less than lethal shotgun, it could have been feasible to use. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the call from dispatch, the information he obtained from the RP, and the fact the bedroom door was barricaded, confirmed his belief Tovar was the intruder. Sgt. Gonzalez said the female was seated on the floor and was sheltering the child by holding the child with both arms. While both were crying, neither victim made any comments during the incident. I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what he believed Tovars intent was when he first observed Tovar standing in the room with the knife. Sgt. Gonzalez said, To inflict like serious bodily harm on someone. Sgt. Gonzalez believed Tovar was intent on injuring somebody. Another break in the interview was taken at this time. After this break, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez several follow-up questions. I asked Sgt. Gonzalez to describe the females position on the floor while holding the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female was sitting on the floor with her feet near her buttocks providing shelter for the child. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the child to be approximately 2 3 years old. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the female to be in her mid-20s. The female had her arms wrapped around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez said the female and child were chest-to-chest facing each other. Sgt. Gonzalez stated the female appeared to be in fear for her life as she was crying. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he believed the female was in fear of her life because she was crying and she was sheltering the child from Tovar by wrapping her arms around the child. Sgt. Gonzalez stated he thought Tovar was going to stab either the female or the child with the knife because of the way Tovar was holding the knife and the way Tovar target scanned by looking at Sgt. Gonzalez and then returning his gaze toward the victims attempting to ascertain which target would be the easiest to stab. Sgt. Gonzalez estimated the knife was approximately three feet away from the female and her child. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.005 By: D.A. Inv. K. Hunsaker Page 9 of 10 Based on his training and experience, I asked Sgt. Gonzalez what possibilities existed with a suspect holding a knife three feet away from a potential victim. Sgt. Gonzalez responded, A person could get stabbed. It takes less than a second. Sgt. Gonzalez did not recall Tovar moving during the encounter. DAI Torres asked if the distance between Tovar and the female and child changed during the encounter and Sgt. Gonzalez stated, No. Sgt. Gonzalez stated after the first shot was fired, Tovar maintained the same position and the knife remained approximately three feet away from the female and child. Sgt. Gonzalez could not remember if Tovar moved toward the female and child after the first shot was fired. Sgt. Gonzalez had no additional information to provide but said, It was just a very dramatic situation at the time. When I asked Sgt. Gonzalez if he had previously encountered Tovar, he said he recognized Tovars name after reviewing the CAD (Computer Aided Dispatch) and he knew Tovar lived in the area. Sgt. Gonzalez said he knew Tovar, but he did not recognize Tovar during the encounter inside 404 Hyland Dr. Sgt. Gonzalez said Tovar had previously registered with him as part of Tovars 290 PC status. I had no additional questions for Sgt. Gonzalez and ended the interview at approximately 1045 hours.
