Torres Page 1 of 4 MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION DECEDENT Name: Anthony Tovar DOB: 07/22/1998 Physical Description: HMA, 53, 130 lbs., Blk/Blk Home Address: 18807 Moro Road, Salinas, CA 93907 Driver License/CII CA Y8169050 / A37472173 MCSO Case FG2304178 MCSO Coroner Case 2023-00685 Santa Cruz County Coroner Case 23-06441 VICTIM Name: Victim 1 VICTIM Name: Victim 2 VICTIM Name: Victim 3 INVOLVED SERGEANT Name: David Gonzalez Agency: Monterey County Sheriff s Office INVOLVED DEPUTY Name: Cristian Pantoja Agency: Monterey County Sheriffs Office NARRATIVE: On 8/11/23 at approximately 1059 hours, Monterey County Sheriff Office (MCSO) Deputy Cristian Pantoja was interviewed regarding his involvement in the Officer Involved Shooting (OIS) that occurred on 08/08/23. Also present during the interview was attorney Terry Leoni (Leoni Law Firm) representing Deputy Pantoja, and District Attorney Investigator (DAI) Kris Hunsaker. The interview was audio recorded (Items TT 1 and TT 2) using my department issued cellular phone. Items TT 1 and TT 2 were later uploaded into digital evidence at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office. Deputy Pantoja confirmed this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.006 By: D.A. Inv. T. Torres Page 2 of 4 compelled to provide a statement. Deputy Pantoja also had the opportunity to consult with his attorney prior to this interview. Deputy Pantoja was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training, and experience. The following is a summary of his responses: Deputy Pantoja said he is employed with the Monterey County Sheriffs Office and is a Deputy in training. Deputy Pantoja has been in the field training program for approximately 2 Â½ months. He has been employed with the Sheriffs Office for 4 years and was a jail deputy prior to his current assignment. Deputy Pantoja has attended the basic police academy and does not hold any auxiliary assignments. Deputy Pantoja has not attended any specialized training other than the police academy. On the day of this interview, Deputy Pantoja was 29 years of age, and his current title is Deputy in training. Deputy Pantoja is issued a Glock 17 Pistol that utilizes a 9 mm round. Deputy Pantoja is also assigned a patrol rifle. The rifle is a Colt rifle that fires a .223 round. The pistol and rifle have an added department-issued flashlight attached to them. The pistol has been issued to Deputy Pantoja for approximately 4 years. The rifle has been issued to him for approximately 1 year. Deputy Pantoja does not carry a backup weapon. Deputy Pantoja performs functions checks before every shift on both of his issued firearms. Deputy Pantoja qualified with both firearms the week he started the field training program. On the day of the incident, Deputy Pantoja was wearing a class A uniform which consists of a shirt with Sheriffs Office patches on both sleeves. He was wearing green class A pants and a duty belt. Deputy Pantoja also had a badge on his left chest and a name plate on the right chest. Deputy Pantoja carries two (2) pairs of handcuffs, radio, flashlight, collapsible baton, Glock 17 pistol, taser, OC spray and two (2) pistol magazines on his duty belt. On the day of the incident Deputy Pantoja was in a marked Sheriffs Office patrol car. The vehicle is equipped with emergency lights and siren. The vehicle is not equipped with a camera. Deputy Pantoja said the Monterey County Sheriffs Office does not issue body worn cameras to deputies. Deputy Pantoja went on to recall the events of the day of the incident. Deputy Pantoja said he was dispatched to a call that was a 911 hang up. He was told by dispatch that a caller had said there was someone with a knife and then the call was disconnected. Deputy Pantoja was finishing a traffic stop at the time he was contacted by dispatch. After getting in his vehicle, a location was given on Hyland Drive. Deputy Pantoja activated his emergency lights and siren and responded to the area. While driving to the location, additional information was being provided to Deputy Pantoja. Deputy Pantoja said he was told that a suspect was locked in a room armed with a knife, with a MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.006 By: D.A. Inv. T. Torres Page 3 of 4 female adult and a child. Upon arriving, Deputy Pantoja said he saw Sgt. Gonzalez running towards the residence where the suspect was located. Deputy Pantoja followed Sgt. Gonzalez into the residence. Deputy Pantoja said due to the severity of the information he was provided, he unholstered his firearm. When he entered the residence, Deputy Pantoja saw a male adult in the living room of the house. He ordered the adult to exit which he did. Sgt. Gonzalez went down a hallway inside of the residence to a closed door. Sgt. Gonzalez attempted to open the door, but it was locked. Sgt. Gonzalez told Deputy Pantoja to take a breach position. Deputy Pantoja believed this meant they would kick the door open. Sgt. Gonzalez kicked the door approximately two (2) times. Deputy Pantoja said he began to feel fear because it was unknown what was inside of the room. Deputy Pantoja said he knew someone had a knife and possible hostages inside of the room. Deputy Pantoja said the door appeared to be barricaded and it opened only slightly after being kicked. Deputy Pantoja said he looked inside of the room, and he could see a female adult who appeared to be holding a small child and was in distress. The female was crying as was the child and they were on the bedroom floor. Deputy Pantoja said the female adult appeared to be in fear for her life. Deputy Pantoja said he was holding his firearm in a low ready position and was scanning the room. Deputy Pantoja said he saw a Hispanic male adult holding what appeared to be a kitchen knife in his hand. Deputy Pantoja said he was afraid because he did not know the suspects abilities with the knife. Deputy Pantoja said he began to give the suspect commands such as drop the knife. Deputy Pantoja said he felt afraid for his life as well as the life of the female and child. The suspect was in close proximity to the victims as well as the deputies. Deputy Pantoja said that the suspect, later identified as Anthony Tovar, was not listening to any of the commands the deputies were giving him. Deputy Pantoja yelled at Tovar and said, look at me. Tovar looked at Deputy Pantoja and waived his hand in a motion that Deputy Pantoja took as go away. Tovar was in a bladed stance and holding the knife out in front of himself. Tovar then began to turn away from Deputy Pantoja and Sgt. Gonzalez towards both victims. Deputy Pantoja said he heard approximately three (3) rounds go off from Sgt. Gonzalezs pistol. Tovar flinched and had a physical reaction to the shots. Deputy Pantoja said he believed the shots had struck Tovar. Tovar then turned completely around with his back to the deputies. He faced both the female and the child with the knife still in his hand. The blade of the knife was pointed at both victims. Deputy Pantoja said it was at this time he believed it was Tovars intention to kill both the woman and child. Tovar took a step in the victims direction with the blade of the knife pointed directly at them. Deputy Pantoja estimated Tovar was only a few feet away from the victims at this time. Deputy Pantoja fired a single shot at Tovar. Tovar stopped and showed a flinch or physical MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.006 By: D.A. Inv. T. Torres Page 4 of 4 reaction to the single shot. Tovar then collapsed with the knife still in his hand. Tovar was on the floor motionless. Deputies forced their way in the room and removed the knife from his hand. Deputies rendered basic first aid to Tovar. Fire and AMR were also requested over the radio. Tovar was still breathing and had a pulse during this time. Fire and AMR arrived and took over first aid efforts. At this time Deputy Pantoja was relived from the scene. The interview ended around this time. RECOMMENDATIONS: Forward to District Attorney Investigative Captain J. Ferreria. DAI Ryan J. McGuirk Chief Investigator Case No.: MCDA 23-0005 Date: 8/14/23 Supplement Report No.: DAI RPT.007 Re: Anthony Tovar / Monterey County Sheriffs Office OIS Page 1 of 8 Investigator: Rachel Maldonado By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 1 of 8 MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION DECEDENT Name: Anthony Tovar DOB: 07/22/1998 Physical Description: HMA, 53, 130 lbs., Blk/Blk Home Address: 18807 Moro Road, Salinas, CA 93907 MCSO Coroner Case 2023-00685 Santa Cruz County Coroner Case 23-06441 VICTIM Name: Jose De Jesus Valdivia Jr. Home Address: 404 Hyland Drive, Salinas, CA 93907 Phone No.: (831) 905-7422 VICTIM Name: Alejandra Guzman Home Address: 404 Hyland Drive, Salinas, CA 93907 VICTIM Name: Elianna Valdivia Home Address: 404 Hyland Drive, Salinas, CA 93907 INVOLVED SERGEANT Name: David Gonzalez Agency: Monterey County Sheriffs Office INVOLVED DEPUTY Name: Cristian Pantoja Agency: Monterey County Sheriffs Office SYNOPSIS: This report documents the contact and interview with Deputy Josue Ramirez regarding the Officer Involved Shooting that occurred on August 8, 2023. Also present during the interview was Attorney Terry Leoni, representing Deputy Ramirez, and Monterey County District Attorney Investigator Justin Bell. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 2 of 8 NARRATIVE: At approximately 1130 hours, I met with Monterey County Sheriffs Office (MCSO) Deputy Josue Ramirez, Attorney Terry Leoni, and Monterey County District Attorney Investigator Justin Bell at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office for an interview. The interview was audio recorded using my department issued digital recorder, and officially began at 1158 hours. It should be noted that due to a break during the interview, there are a total of two audio recordings for this interview. The first interview will be labeled Interview Part 1, and the second, Interview Part 2. Deputy Ramirez stated that this interview was voluntary, and he was not ordered, coerced, or compelled to provide a statement. He also had the opportunity to consult with his attorney prior to this interview. Deputy Ramirez was asked a series of questions regarding his assignment, equipment, training, and experience. The following is a summary of his responses: Deputy Ramirez is currently assigned to the patrol division of the Monterey County Sheriffs Office (MCSO), which was the capacity he was working at the time of the Officer Involved Shooting (OIS). Deputy Ramirez was also a breacher on the MCSO SWAT team, a drone operator, and a Field Training Officer (FTO). Deputy Ramirez has been a sworn deputy with MCSO since 2015 (approximately 8 years). He did not work for any other departments prior to MCSO. Deputy Ramirezs badge/CAD number is R8475, and on the day of the OIS his call sign was 1Z3. Deputy Ramirez is 31 years old. Deputy Ramirez has training in the police academy, CPR training, less lethal force options training and arrest and control techniques training. He has not yet attended CIT training for Crisis Intervention or Critical Incidents. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 3 of 8 On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirez was carrying the following firearm: Glock 17, 9mm Primary Duty Weapon This firearm is department-issued. Deputy Ramirez has had this firearm for over 5 years. The only modifications were a mounted flashlight and grip additions. He last qualified with this weapon in March of 2023, which was also the last time he did a function check. The magazine was loaded to capacity (17 rounds) plus one in the chamber. Deputy Ramirez did not fire his weapon during this incident. At the time of his response to the scene, Deputy Ramirez was dressed in his patrol uniform which consisted of a tan shirt, green BDU uniform pants, a tan outer carrier bearing a badge, name plate, MCSO patches on both sleeves and a patch on the back of the carrier which read Sheriff. Also on the carrier were a flashlight, pepper spray, taser, baton, handcuffs, magazines, and an admin pocket with pens and a notepad. Deputy Ramirez wore a duty belt with only his firearm which was in a drop-down holster attached to his leg. He also wore tactical boots. On the day of the OIS, Deputy Ramirezs assigned vehicle was patrol unit 3089. Deputy Ramirez was working in an FTO capacity the evening of the shooting, and he shared this vehicle with his trainee, Deputy Pantoja, who conducted an inspection on the vehicle prior to the start of the shift. Deputy Ramirez believed all the equipment in the vehicle was functioning. The vehicle was equipped with a less lethal shotgun. Deputy Ramirez said the vehicle usually has a WRAP, which is a device used to restrain combative individuals. He did not know if the WRAP was in the trunk that evening since he did not inspect the vehicle. The vehicle was not equipped with any cameras. Deputy Ramirez was then asked to explain in his own words the circumstances surrounding this OIS. The following is a summary of his statement: MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 4 of 8 Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja were on patrol and had just cleared a traffic stop in the city of Salinas at Boronda Road and North Main St. Dispatch advised of a 911 hangup call where a reporting party (RP) reported a man was inside of his residence with a knife. While enroute to the scene, dispatch updated something regarding a mother and a child; however, due to the chaos he, could not recall any more details. Deputy Pantoja was driving, and they headed towards the residence with lights and sirens activated. Deputy Ramirez was the passenger and was talking to Deputy Pantoja making sure they knew where they were going and the fastest route to take. Deputy Ramirez heard Sergeant David Gonzalez advise he had arrived on scene just a few seconds before he and Deputy Pantoja arrived. Deputy Ramirez saw Sergeant Gonzalez speaking with a male outside in front of the house. As they were exiting the vehicle, they saw Sergeant Gonzalez run into the home. Deputy Pantoja immediately ran after Sergeant Gonzalez. Deputy Ramirez immediately followed Deputy Pantoja. As he entered the home, Deputy Ramirez could see Sergeant Gonzalez at the right side of a door in a hallway just past the kitchen. Deputy Pantoja met and stood to the left of that same door. Sergeant Gonzalez began to kick in the door as Deputy Ramirez arrived and stood directly behind Deputy Pantoja. He said the room was at the northeast corner of the home. As the door was kicked open, they noticed it was obstructed by an object, and they could not enter. Deputy Ramirez could not see inside, but he knew Deputy Pantoja and Sergeant Gonzalez were challenging someone as they shouted, Drop the knife. As this was going on, Deputy Ramirez was able to see into the opposite side of the room where a mother and a child were on the floor. He described them as being terrified, trembling, and hugging each other. Deputy Ramirez said commands continued towards the suspect to drop the knife. Deputy Ramirez said he also made commands to drop the knife even though he could not see the suspect. Deputy MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 5 of 8 Ramirez then heard a firearm discharge followed by more commands to drop the knife. Deputy Ramirez heard a firearm discharge again, and then they entered the room. As they entered, Deputy Ramirez could see the suspect on the floor. He also saw the knife. Deputy Ramirez went directly to the mother and child, got them up and escorted them out of the room. Deputy Ramirez returned to the room, handcuffed the suspect, turned him over and began to render medical aid (refer to the audio recording for details on Deputy Ramirezs efforts to treat the suspect). AMR and fire personnel arrived a short time later and took over medical treatment of the suspect. Deputy Ramirez recalled that the officers present during the shooting were Sergeant Gonzalez, Deputy Pantoja, Deputy Perez and himself. I followed up with questions for Deputy Ramirez regarding his mindset during this incident. After hearing initial radio traffic, Deputy Ramirez was in fear for the mother and child. He said he has two daughters himself, so this was terrifying. Deputy Ramirez said he had no prior knowledge of the suspect, and he did not know who the suspect was. Deputy Ramirez said he had no interactions with the suspect prior to the shooting, and the only time he saw him was after deputies entered the room. Prior to the shooting, Deputy Ramirez did not hear or see the suspect. Deputy Ramirez did not recall if any description of the suspect was broadcasted prior to his arrival. Deputy Ramirezs mindset upon arrival was that he needed to be with his sergeant and Deputy Pantoja. He said he did not know if Sergeant Gonzalez heard or saw something, but since he ran into the house by himself, Deputy Pantoja and Deputy Ramirez immediately followed him so they could go in together. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 6 of 8 Deputy Ramirez said there was no plan formulated during this incident, and everything happened so quickly that he could only react to the other officers actions. Deputy Ramirez did not hear communication during the call amongst officers, but he was the last to walk up. As he walked up, he put his hand on the shoulder of Deputy Pantoja in preparation for room entry and to alert Deputy Pantoja that Deputy Ramirez was behind him. This was for tactical purposes as he was trained during SWAT. Deputy Ramirez said that had they been able to enter the room at that point, he would have remained with Deputy Pantoja and provided him direction while dealing with the situation. Due to the circumstances, Deputy Ramirez was not able to do this. Upon arrival at the scene, Deputy Ramirez recalled Sergeant Gonzalez talking to a male he believed to be the reporting party. The male appeared to be in a state of panic. Deputy Ramirez did not hear their exchange. Deputy Ramirez did not recall anyone on scene verbally identify themselves as law enforcement. He said the command of drop the knife was given several times. He said it was more than two. He could not recall any background noise that would obstruct the suspects ability to hear commands. Deputy Ramirez described the layout of the residence as a living room that feeds into the kitchen. The kitchen leads to a hallway where the door to the room is located. This was where the four officers were positioned as they challenged the suspect. From where he was standing in the hallway, Deputy Ramirez estimated he was 10 feet from the mother and child in the room. Deputy Ramirez said he did not discharge his weapon. Sergeant Gonzalez and Deputy Pantoja discharged their weapons. I asked Deputy Ramirez what he thought the suspect was trying to do. He mentioned there were many unknowns regarding the suspect and he was worried he would violently hurt the mother and MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 7 of 8 the little girl. He was thinking the worst based on the fact he believed the suspect was a random person in the home, and he was worried of a violent sexual assault. DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez if any information he received gave him the sense of the type of call this was, specifically to know whether this was a stranger or a domestic violence situation. Deputy Ramirez responded that he could not discern what type of call it was, nor could he know if there were issues with the RP. In his mind, Deputy Ramirez understood this to be a hostage situation based on the information he was given. Deputy Ramirez said that there were no other force options available to deal with the situation. He said that everything happened very quickly and the deputies that shot had to instantly react to what was in front of them. From the time they entered the home until the time of the shots, Deputy Ramirez estimated it was less than a minute. In his mind, when he saw the door was intentionally blocked by the suspect, he believed the suspect was trying to prevent anyone from entering the room. DAI Bell asked Deputy Ramirez about the potential danger of a person with a knife, based on his training and experience. He said a knife can cause severe damage or life-threatening injuries. It could take seconds for a person with a knife to severely injure someone. In this situation, there was not enough time to run to a vehicle to get a less lethal option. When they arrived, the immediate instinct was to be with Sergeant Gonzalez, so he was not by himself, and Deputy Ramirez needed to remain with Deputy Pantoja. Deputy Ramirez said that upon opening the door, it opened about a foot. With the layout of the hallway and the amount of space available, they would not have been able to deploy a taser or other less lethal options. Deputy Ramirez did not have a good angle or view to deploy one of these options. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.007 By: D.A. Inv. Maldonado Page 8 of 8 This concluded the interview of Deputy Ramirez. The interview was concluded at 1241 hours. RECOMMENDATIONS: Forward to Deputy District Attorney Investigative Captain J. Ferreria. EVIDENCE: ITEM NO. Inv. J. Bell Page 2 of 6 SYNOPSIS: This report summarizes the interview of witness Deputy Jason Perez. SUMMARY: On 8/11/2023 at approximately 1305 hours, Investigator Maldonado and I interviewed witness Deputy Jason Perez at the Monterey County District Attorneys Office in Salinas. The interview was regarding the deputy involved shooting that occurred on 8/11/2023 in the city of Salinas. Deputy Perez was represented by his attorney, Terry Leoni from Full Service Labor & Employment Law Firm. I audio recorded the interview and uploaded the interview to evidence.com as JB-1. Deputy Perez confirmed he was present to provide a voluntary statement, and that he had been able to consult with his attorney prior the interview. Deputy Perez provided the following information about his assignment, training, equipment and uniform: Background And Experience Name Jason Perez Agency Monterey County Sheriffs Office Date of Hire March 3, 2013 Rank Deputy Age 41 years old Years of Law Enforcement Experience 10 Years of law Enforcement Experience 4 Years of Patrol experience Current Assignment Patrol Auxiliary Assignments Drone team Specialized Training Police Academy, Field Training program Annual departmental firearms training Pistol and Rifle qualification Less Lethal training on taser, OC spray, baton, less lethal shotgun and Pepper ball MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.008 By: D.A. Inv. J. Approximately 2 years Modifications/Accessories Department approved flashlight Qualification Date June of 2023 Magazine Capacity and Loadout 17 rounds in the magazines plus one in the chamber Last function check Cleaned after last qualification MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.008 By: D.A. Inv. J. Bell Page 4 of 6 Deputy Perez told me the following in summary: Deputy Perez is normally assigned to coastal patrol, but they were short staffed in Salinas and he volunteered to be reassigned. Deputy Perez was with Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja at a traffic stop at Boronda Rd. and North Main Street. At approximately 2132, hours he received a dispatch call from Monterey County Communications that a male was reporting that a subject was in his house with a knife locked in a room. He said the details were vague at that time. Deputy Perez responded to 404 Hyland Drive with lights and sirens (code 3) behind Deputy Ramirez and Deputy Pantoja. He received updates that the reporting party (RP) was asking them to hurry, and said that the subject was in the house with his wife with a knife. Deputy Perez heard Sgt. Gonzales attach himself to the call. They received an update that there was a man with a knife locked in a room with the callers wife and child. Sgt. Gonzales arrived and updated over the radio that he was being flagged down by a male. Deputy Perez arrived on scene shortly after. Deputy Perez saw Deputy Pantoja and Deputy Ramirez running towards the front of the house. Deputy Perez started running after them then paused for a second and thought that he should get the less lethal shotgun out of his trunk. Deputy Perez saw Sgt. Gonzales basically leap into the house and he felt that Sgt. Gonzales had more information because he had arrived first and had spoken to the RP already. Based on Sgt. Gonzales actions and the information he had already received, Deputy Perez felt that the circumstances were so exigent that there was not time to go back and get the less lethal shotgun. Deputy Perez ran towards the house. Deputy Perez said based on the information he had received from dispatch told him that they needed to get into the house quickly. He felt that the subjects were in danger, and he felt that there was just no time. Based on the information he had, he felt that the suspects intention was to harm the woman and child or the responding deputies. When Deputy Perez got to the front door of the residence, he, the RP, and another male were standing just outside the house and he told them to get farther away. When he was inside, he could hear kicking bang bang and the voice of Sgt. Gonzales yelling open the door, open the door When Deputy Perez got to the hallway, he could see Sgt. Gonzales to the right and Deputy MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.008 By: D.A. Inv. J. Bell Page 5 of 6 Pantoja a little bit to the left. Deputy Perez was right behind Deputy Ramirez. He could see that the door was open 1.5 to 2 feet and appeared to be barricaded by a dresser with a mirror attached to it. He could see the deputies trying to push it but it would not move. At that time all he could see through the opening in the door was the dresser blocking the doorway and the back wall of the room. Deputy Perez could not see the mother and child or the suspect in the room. He then heard drop the knife, drop the knife before hearing a bang, and then another bang. He said there was about 5 seconds between the first bang and the second bang. I asked if there was anything going on at the time of the commands to drop the knife that would have prevented someone from hearing the deputies. He said there was not. I asked if he heard any announcements that it was the police or sheriffs department, and he said, no. When Deputy Perez saw that the door was barricaded, Deputy Perez thought that meant that the victims were in danger. That meant that the suspect was not going to come out, and was going to harm the child or the mother, because he had barricaded himself in with them. Deputy Perez turned around and saw the RP behind him and had to tell him to get back outside. Deputy Perez had to help get the door open because it was still barricaded. He saw the suspect on the ground wounded and the mother and child huddled over in a fetal position crying with the mother bear hugging the child. They ended up breaking the door basically in half and climbed over the dresser to get inside the bedroom. Deputy Perez pulled the mother and child out of the room and checked them to make sure they were okay. A little later AMR Ambulance arrived. Deputy Perez put the mother and child into his patrol car, and put the husband into another patrol car. Deputy Perez was told to remain with Deputy Pantoja and they did not discuss anything about the incident. I asked, based on his training and experience, what threat someone with a knife posed. He said a knife could easily kill or seriously injure the victims. I asked if Deputy Perez had the less lethal shotgun upon his arrival into the house, if it could have changed the way the situation was handled. Deputy Perez said he did not think so. MONTEREY COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION Case : MCDA 23-0005 Supplement : DAI RPT.008 By: D.A. Inv. J. Bell Page 6 of 6 Firstly, the less lethal shotgun has a standoff distance. Based on the fact that it was such a small room he would not have been able to deploy it safely. Additionally, if the less lethal shotgun was not effective, the suspect could have been angered and then taken out his aggression on the victims while they were barricaded in the room. He said that door was so effectively barricaded that it took the deputies substantial time and effort to get the door open even after the suspect was down. Deputy Perez also described that he could not see the suspect from his position in the hallway, and that he would have needed to get around and in front of the other deputies before he would have an opportunity to use it, and in doing so he would have removed their ability to deploy lethal force and have lethal cover. Deputy Perez said he did not hear any sound from inside the room prior to the shooting, and could not see the suspect. He did not hear any words from the suspect. He did not have any prior knowledge of the suspect or the residence they had entered. Deputy Perez thought that maybe 1 or 2 minutes passed between his arrival on scene and the shooting. He said the whole scene was so dynamic and fast, everything happened in a split- second decision. Deputy Perez never fired his weapon. Deputy Perez said he did not render medical aid to the suspect because he was responsible for the victim and her child. Deputy Perez said he did not think they had any other force options based on how quickly the events transpired. They did not even get a chance to think about using OC or other options. He said OC also would not have been a good option because everyone would have been effected by it in such a confined space, and they would have lost control over the whole situation. He felt that if they had tried a taser, people are aware of how to defeat the taser. He felt if they had tried to tase the suspect and it failed, he would have been angered into action to harm the victim and her child. Deputy Perez said the suspect had the advantage over them the entire time. Based on what Deputy Perez saw once in the room, he understood the suspect was a lunge away from the victims and it would have taken less than a second for him to harm them. RECOMMENDATIONS: Attach to OIS investigative report. Ryan J. Quaglia Page 2 of 3 MENTIONED Name: Isabella Rotti, Autopsy Technician Agency: Santa Cruz County Sheriffs Office SUMMARY: At the time of this investigation, I was employed as a Monterey County District Attorneys Office (MCDA) Investigator (DAI). On Friday, August 11th, 2023, I was assigned to attend the autopsy of decedent Anthony Tovar at the Santa Cruz County Sheriffs Office (SCSO) Coroner Autopsy Suite. The autopsy was conducted by Chief Forensic Pathologist Dr. Stephany Fiore, it began around 0900 hours and concluded at around 1500 hours. SCSO Criminalist Karyn Crawford, and Autopsy Technicians Michelle Novak and Isabella Rotti were assisting. Monterey County District Attorney Investigative Aide (DAIA) Tanya Nava and DAIA Vanessa Valle were in attendance. Nava, Valle, and I witnessed the autopsy from a viewing room adjoined to the autopsy suite. We viewed the autopsy suite directly through a glass partition and electronically via closed circuit television monitoring. The rooms were equipped with two-way communication via an intercom system. I observed the decedent in a white body bag labeled as Anthony Tovar and sealed with bag lock 85571. I witnessed Criminalist Crawford taking photographs to document the postmortem examination. The RP, stated there was a male subject insTclehis residence. The male was in a bedroom, with The male was armed with a knife. At approximately 2135 HRS, SGT D GONZALEZ, FTO RAMIREZ, Deputy C PANTOJA, and Deputy J PEREZ arrived on scene. At approximately 2136 HRS, radio traffic advising shots fired was put out. Deputy SOTO and I responded from the area of Highway 1 and Merritt St, Castroville. We responded with emergency lights and siren. VVhile en route to the incident, I assumed the role of Patrol Supervisor, as the only on duty supervisor was involved in the incident. I contacted Commander N DAVIS, via cellular telephone, advised of the deputies involved in a shooting, and stated more information would be provided as soon as I arrived on scene. At approximately 2147 HRS, upon arrival on scene, I advised Deputy SOTO to start a crime scene log and establish the entry/exit point at the intersection of El Rancho Way and Hyland Dr, Salinas. I then contacted SGT GONZALEZ, who was standing out in front of the residence. I confirmed SGT GONZALEZ had no injuries and obtained a Public Safety Statement. SGT GONZALEZ stated he fired 1 round from his department-issued Glock 17M. When the suspect did not react to this, he fired 2, or possibly 3, more rounds from his handgun. SGT GONZALEZ stated there were no outstanding subjects, no other persons were injured, and the incident occurred in the bedroom, located to the rear of the residence. Controlled Document, Duplication of Re-Issuance Controlled by Law Print Date / Time FIie Number 8/31/2023 8:26:00 AM G2304178.DOC Page Number 1 of 4 MONTEREY COUNTY SHERIFF 1414 Natividad Road Salinas, CA 93906 CA0270000 Phone (831) 755-3700 Fax (831) 755-381 O I then entered the residence, where I found Salinas Fire personnel, as well as AMR Medical personnel, providing medical treatment to the male subject. I checked on FTO RAMIREZ and Deputy C PANTOJA. Both advised they had no injuries. FTO RAMIREZ stated he did not engage the subject, as Deputy PANTOJA and SGT GONZALEZ were positioned in front of him at the time of the incident. I then spoke with Deputy PANTOJA. I obtained a Public Safety Statement from Deputy PANTOJA. Deputy PANTOJA stated he fired 1 round from his department-issued Glock 17M. Deputy PANTOJA stated there were no outstanding subjects, no other persons were injured, and the incident occurred in the bedroom. After speaking with SGT GONZALEZ and Deputy PANTOJA, it was apparent there was no longer any threat to the residents, deputies, or the general public. The incident was contained to the bedroom, inside the residence. There were no outstanding suspects, and all involved parties were accounted for. Several minutes later, FTO MEILAN and Deputy M BROWN arrived on scene. I had them relieve FTO RAMIREZ and stand by in the bedroom for scene security. Deputy PANTOJA was then placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy J PEREZ, who stated he was not involved in the incident. SGT GONZALEZ was placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy ROMERO. FTO RAMIREZ was placed in a marked patrol vehicle with Deputy MORAN. They were advised to not talk to anyone about the incident, whether it was family, or other law enforcement officers. SGT GONZALEZ, FTO RAMIREZ and Deputy PANTOJA were then taken to the Central Patrol Station, Salinas. The mother and child had already been removed from the residence and were secured in a patrol vehicle. A short time later, Commander N DAVIS and Commander J SMITH arrived on the scene. Both were briefed and provided with as much information as possible. At the lime, the identity of the subject was unknown. He did look familiar, but I could not recall his name at the time. I did recall him being contacted while investigating a sexual assault at a residence across the street, down an alleyway. I could not recall the address but did recall contacting him while assisting with that case. This information was later passed on to investigators. None of the involved deputies were able to identify the male. Monterey County District Attorneys Office Investigators arrived on the scene, as well as detectives from the Monterey County Sheriffs Office. Scene security was maintained by Monterey County Sheriffs Office deputies, as well as Salinas Police Officers. The investigation was taken over by the Monterey County District Attorneys Office Investigators. Nothing further from this deputy at this lime. Case continued with Monterey County District Attorneys Office. Controlled Document, Duplication of Rewlssuance Controlled by Law Print Date I Time File Number 8/31/2023 8:26: 00 AM G2304178. Approved by : KENNEDYNM Date : 08/10/2023 09:23 AM Controlled Document, DupllcaUon of Re-Issuance Controlled by Law Print Date I Time File Number 8/31/2023 8:26:00 AM G2304178.S01 Page Number 1 of 1 MONTEREY COUNTY SHERIFF 1414 Natividad Road Salinas, CA 93906 Case Number FG2304178 Date 08/09/23 Supplement 02 CA0270000 Phone (831) 755-3700 Fax (831) 755-3810 Officer BROWNMM On 8/8/2023, at about 2130 hours, deputies were dispatched to Hyland Or., Salinas on the report of an unknown male suspect, with a knife, inside the residence. FTO J. Meilan and I began to drive toward the residence. At about 2136 hours, deputies advised, via radio, shots were fired, and the suspect was shot. FTO Meilan and I responded with our emergency overhead lights and sirens activated from Highway 1 and Molera Rd. Upon arrival, at about 2147 hours, we were met on scene with multiple outside agencies to include, Salinas Police Department (SPD), Salinas Fire Department (SFD), and American Medical Response (AMR). The Sheriff Deputies already on scene were Sergeant D. Gonzalez, FTO J. Ramirez, FTO E. Schumacher, Deputy C. Pantoja, and Deputy A. Soto. I exited my patrol vehicle and I saw Sheriffs Office crime scene tape blocked off at the intersection of Hyland Dr., and El Rancho Wy. I entered the secured area and entered the residence. Once I was inside the residence, I saw SFD and AMR personnel treating a victim in a rear bedroom. At 2202 hours, SFD announced the time of death which was approved by Dr. _,f Natividad Medical Center (NMC). A short time later, I contacted - and he advised he was assigned to Medic Engine 2. I also contacted AMR-and he advised he was assigned to unit 48. All AMR and SFD personnel left the scene. I then took multiple digital images of the crime scene. The images were of the outside of the residence, inside the living room, kitchen, bedrooms, the back bedroom where the shooting occurred, of the decedent, and a knife. I later uploaded the digital images to the Monterey County Sheriffs Office Image Swap database. I then remained in the residence, just outside of the bedroom, with the decedent and the knife lying near his body to keep the scene secure. I was later relieved from the crime scene by Monterey County Sheriffs Detectives and Monterey County District Attorneys Office Investigators. Nothing further from this deputy. Sgt. Kennedy. He asked me to respond to-yland Dr. in Salinas to assist with an investigation of a shooting. I arrived on scene and was informed that the Monterey County District Attorneys Office would be handling the investigation of the incident. I was told that they would be utilizing the services of the Sheriffs Office Forensic Evidence Technicians to document the scene and collect evidence. I was asked to remain on scene and assist s she processed the crime scene. During the investigation, a key fob with a Mercedes logo was found in the victims pockets. I offered to walk the neighborhood in search of a Mercedes associated to the keys. I walked through the alley across the street from-yland Dr. with DAI Captain Ferreria. We located a 2001 black Mercedes (CA License Plate 7DAX938) parked in the alley. I returned to the scene and collected the key. I returned to the vehicle and the key unlocked the vehicle. On the front passenger seat, Cap. Ferreria found several pieces of mail with the name Anthony Tovar on them. I contacted the Monterey County Records Department and asked them to conduct a record check on Anthony Tovar with the approximate age range of twenty-five to thirty years old. They advised that they located an Anthony Tovar (7/22/98). I asked them to send a photo of Tovar. They emailed me a photo of Tovar and I forwarded the photo to Capt. Ferreria to assist with identification. I then remained on scene until the scene was released to the homeowner. Case continues. MEMORANDUM DATE: November 21, 2023 TO: Mr. Alexander Tirona FROM: Chief White SUBJECT: NOTICE OF FINDINGS, IA NO. 23-07 The investigation into the above referenced personnel complaint investigation has been completed. A review of the investigation has led to the following classifications for each allegation, based on the preponderance of the evidence standard: ALLEGATION 1. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Tirona, while on-duty, engaged in disgraceful conduct that adversely affected the employee/employer relationship when he told another officer, following an officer involved shooting, to get rid of a prohibited knife he knew the officer possessed in an apparent effort to cover up the violation. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(o) Criminal, dishonest, infamous or disgraceful conduct adversely affecting the employee/employer relationship, whether on- or off-duty. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. - Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. ALLEGATION 2. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Tirona, while on-duty, violated a misdemeanor statute when he told another officer, following an officer involved shooting, to get rid of a prohibited knife he knew the officer possessed in an apparent effort to cover up the violation. CLASSIFICATION: Not sustained. Adjudication, IA No. IA23-07 Page 2 ALLEGATION 3. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Tirona, while on-duty, engaged in conduct which any employee knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a member of the Department or which is contrary to good order, efficiency or morale, or which tends to reflect unfavorably upon the Department or its members, when he told another officer, following an officer involved shooting, to get rid of a prohibited knife he knew the officer possessed in an apparent effort to cover up the violation. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.5(aa) Any other on-duty or off-duty conduct which any employee knows or reasonably should know is unbecoming a member of the Department or which is contrary to good order, efficiency or morale, or which tends to reflect unfavorably upon the Department or its members. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. 3. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 r. Any act or conduct either during or outside duty hours which is incompatible or inconsistent with City employment or which is conduct unbecoming City employment ALLEGATION 4. The Department alleges that on August 18, 2023, Officer Tirona, while on-duty, failed to promptly report activities on the part of another officers possession of a prohibited knife. CLASSIFICATION: Sustained RULE, REGULATION, ORDER AND STATUTORY VIOLATIONS: 1. Police Department Policy Manual Policy 320.4.2(f) Failure of any employee to promptly and fully report activities on their own part or the part of any other employee where such activities may result in criminal prosecution or discipline under this policy. 2. Martinez Civil Service Rule 9.2 j. Violation of any Department rule or any City, County, State or Federal law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. LEVEL OF DISCIPLINE Unable to impose discipline as you are no longer employed with this agency. NOTICE TO EMPLOYEE The above classifications are limited to allegations in which you were the subject. A copy of this memorandum will be placed in your personnel file. Adjudication, IA No. IA23-07 Page 3 You can review the completed investigation by contacting Executive Assistant Mariette Cesar. LAKE COUNTY SHERIFFS OFFICE 1220 Martin Street P.O.Box 489 Lakeport, California 95453 Coroner Corrections Patrol/Investigations Administration Central Dispatch (707) 262-4240 (707) 262-4200 (707) 262-4200 (707) 263-2690 (707) 262-4215 Rob Howe Sheriff/Coroner Captain Chris Chwialkowski Patrol Division Commander RE: Deadly Force Review Board Report and Findings have reviewed the memo dated March 26, 2024, authored by Lt. Gavin Wells regarding the Use of Force Review Board Findings following an inquiry into the fatal shooting of Richard Pyorre (age 53) by Deputy Ben Moore on November 16, 2023. have reviewed the accompanying Internal Administrative Investigation report (2023-00014) and the accompanying attachments. The findings of the Deadly Force Review Board were that Deputy Ben Moores actions related to his involvement in a shooting on November 16, 2023 were appropriate and within policy. further found that Deputy Moore was in compliance with applicable training, and that his use of deadly force in this situation was appropriate for the following reasons: Richard Pyorre presented an immediate and severe threat to Deputy Moore at the time force was applied. Richard Pyorre was in immediate possession of a firearm. There were no other reasonable options available to Deputy Moore. Use of impact weapons, electronic control devices, pepper spray, or hands-on techniques were not viable options. Deputy Moore is well trained in use of force issues and techniques. Deputy Moore perceived Richard Pyorre to be an imminent threat to his life. Richard Pyorre presented a great potential for injury to Deputy Moore, other peace officers on scene and to members of the public. There was an immediate need to prevent Richard Pyorre from continuing his activity as well as to stop him from committing a firearm attack on Deputy Moore himself. Deputy Moore delivered deadly force until he no longer perceived Pyorre to be a threat. Deputy Moores ammunition, uniform, and firearm were all in compliance with departmental regulations. Deputy Moore appropriately used his recording devices to memorialize the incident. RECOMMENDATIONS: No disciplinary action regarding Deputy Moores compliance with policies and procedures should be brought against him. With Regards, Rob Howe ez: ge Date: S- Le. CY Sheriff Coroner

MERCED COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEYS OFFICE Nicole A. Silveira District Attorney June 28, 2024 Merced Police Department Attn: Chief Steven Stanfield 611 W. 22 Street Merced, CA 95340 Re: Officer Wilkins Officer Involved Shooting October 26, 2023 Chief Stanfield, The Merced County District Attorneys Office has conducted an investigation into the fatal officer- involved shooting of Gilbert Garibay by Officers Wilkins on October 26, 2023. The criminal investigation was led by the Merced Police Department. The District Attorneys Office Bureau of Investigations conducted a review of the incident. The purpose of the investigation by the District Attorneys Office is to determine if any violation of criminal law may have occurred on the part of either officer. A prosecutor should file criminal charges only if the prosecutor reasonably believes that the charges are supported by probable cause, that admissible evidence will be sufficient to support conviction beyond reasonable doubt, and that the decision to the charge is in the interest of justice. Possible criminal charges against Officer Wilkins are: Possible criminal charges against an officer involved in a shooting include murder (Penal Code Section 187); manslaughter (Penal Code Section 192); assault with a deadly weapon (Penal Code Section 245); and assault by a police officer (Penal Code Section 149). In order to convict an officer of any of these charges, however, it would be necessary to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that no legal justifications existed for the officers actions. (People v. Adrian (1982) 135 Cal.App.3d 335, 340-342.) Justifications for an officers actions are set forth in Penal Code Sections 196, 197 and 835a. Pursuant to Penal Code Section 835a, peace officers may use deadly force, when necessary, in defense of human life. In decision should be evaluated from the perspective of a reasonable officer in the same situation, based on the totality of the circumstances known at the time, rather than the benefit of hindsight. The totality of the circumstances should include considering situations in which officers are forced to make quick judgments about using force. Penal Code Section 835a further provides a peace officer is justified in using deadly force when the officer reasonably believes, based on the totality of the 550 W. Main Street Merced, CA 95340 Telephone (209) 385-7381 Fax (209) 725-3669 Victim Witness Telephone (209) 385-7385 445 I Street Los Banos, CA 95635 Telephone (209) 710-6070 Fax (209) 724-4066 circumstances such force is necessary to defend against imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury. In this case, Officer Wilkins responded to a dispatch call surrounding a subject who was possibly suicidal. Officer Kusomo also arrived on scene at some point to assist. While on scene, Officer Wilkins stated over the radio that he had one at gunpoint, has a knife wont put it down. He then stated, responsible walking towards us with knife. Body camera footage depicts Garibay opening a folding knife and Officer Wilkins then drawing his firearm. He warned Garibay to drop the knife. Investigators estimated Garibay was approximately 10 feet from Officer Wilkins at this point. Garibay then advanced toward Officer Wilkins while Officer Wilkins advised him to drop the knife seven times. Garibay told the officers shoot me three separate times. Both officers continued to tell Garibay to drop the knife. Officer Wilkins retreated as Garibay advanced with the knife as he continued to give commands including youre going to shot, stop. During the entirety of the contact, it is estimated that Garibay advanced towards Officer Kusomo and Officer Wilkins over 78 feet as they retreated and gave commands. After giving multiple commands and the subject failing to comply, Officer Wilkins fired four rounds from his firearm. Officer Kusomo fired three rounds. Garibay died from gunshot wounds. Based on Investigator Nelsons training and experience, individuals with sharp weapons can present fatal danger to others within 21 feet of others. Here, Officer Wilkins gave multiple commands and gave Garibay several opportunities to comply before resorting to deadly force as Garibay closed the distance between himself and Officer Wilkins. Although Officer Wilkins did not give a statement specifically stating what his state of mind was at the time of using deadly force, circumstantial evidence along with Investigator Nelsons opinion support the conclusion that Officer Wilkins reasonably believed it was necessary to defend against imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury. Officer Wilkins was justified in using deadly force in this case. Respectfully submitted, Nicole A. ..........................................................................................................................................17 FACTUAL SUMMARY On October 26, 2023, at 0055 hours, Merced Police Department (MPD) received a call from Jy HE (01d the dispatcher there was a man in the center median of M Street, Merced who tried to jump in front of his pickup. J stayed on the phone with the dispatcher and made a u-turn so he could keep an eye on the subject. Jj was still on the phone with the dispatcher when MPD Officers Brandon Wilkins and Saggalih Kusumo arrived in the 3200 block of M Street. Jj was north of the officers and observed the subject through his side mirror. When J rolled down his window, he could hear the officers giving orders to the subject, which included, Drop the knife. ggg used his cell phone to record the incident. The subject in the median was later identified as Gilbert Garibay. Garibay walked directly in front of Officer Wilkins patrol vehicle as Officer Wilkins arrived. Garibay was seen holding an object in his right hand. Garibay then used his left hand to open the folding knife he was holding in his right hand. Officer Wilkins unholstered his duty weapon and pointed it at Garibay. Officer Wilkins used a loud voice and said, drop the knife now. Officer Kusumo also told Garibay to drop the knife. Officer Wilkins announced over the radio that he had one person at gunpoint and that person had a knife. Both officers retreated by walking backwards. Garibay stated, Shoot me. Garibay continued to hold the open knife in his right hand and advanced towards the officers. Several more announcements were made by both officers for Garibay to, Drop the knife. Garibay said shoot me two more times and then began to walk faster towards Officer Wilkins. According to the measurements provided by MPDs Crime Scene Response Teams diagram Officer Wilkins walked backwards approximately 78 feet and 10 inches. This measurement was taken from the left front tire of Officer Wilkins patrol unit and where Garibays knife was found. Officer Wilkins then announced, Youre going to get shot, stop. Officer Wilkins fired his duty weapon four times at Garibay, and Officer Kusumo fired her duty weapon three times at Garibay. Medical aid was provided to Garibay immediately following the shooting by Officer Wilkins. Responding officers also assisted in providing medical aid and relayed over the radio that it was safe for emergency medical services (EMS) personnel to come to their location. Medical aid continued until Garibay was pronounced deceased at 0109 hours, by the Riggs Paramedic Jeffrey Kuhne. DISPATCH LOG / RECORDINGS I reviewed the 911 call made by gg and the radio traffic provided by MPD. The following is a short summary of the 911 call to MPD Dispatch. gg told the dispatcher, I just had a guy like try to kill himself in front of my truck. Jj explained that the guy was in the median and he dove in front of my truck. J said he had to swerve around him. Jy described the area as M Street, near Jack in the Box. JJ described the subject as wearing green pants and a black sweatshirt. GE also added that the subject was wearing glasses and a tan hat. The dispatcher told gj that an officer would meet with him. The dispatcher broadcast over the radio there was a subject with 913 thoughts. This is the code for suicide. The dispatcher relayed that the reporting party was going to be at M Street and Collins Drive. The following is a summary of the radio communication between Office Wilkins and MPD Dispatch. Officer Wilkins radioed that he was out with both parties. Officer Wilkins radioed, approximately 25 seconds later, one at gunpoint, has a knife wont put it down. Nine seconds after that transmission, Page 3 Page 4 Officer Wilkins radioed responsible walking towards us with knife and just 12 seconds after that radio transmission, Officer Wilkins radioed shots fired, shots fired. INVOLVED OFFICER STATEMENTS Officer Brandon Wilkins and Officer Kusumo declined to give voluntary statements to MPD detectives. OFFICER WILKINS ROUND COUNT On October 26, 2023, at 0323 hours, Detective Rocha and Detective Lupian conducted a round count of Officer Wilkins firearm. Officer Wilkins had a Sig Sauer P320 9mm (serial number 58H267387). There were 17 live rounds in magazine 1 and 1 live round chambered for a total of 18 rounds. The capacity of magazine 1 is 21 rounds. Fully loaded, Officer Wilkins firearm holds 22 rounds. The number of rounds remaining in the firearm is consistent with the evidence showing he fired at Garibay a total of four times. No rounds were missing from Officer Wilkins remaining two magazines. OFFICER KUSUMOS ROUND COUNT On October 26, 2023, at 0353 hours, Detective Rocha and Detective Lupian conducted a round count of Officer Kusumos firearm. Officer Kusumo had a department issued Simth and Wesson M&P 9mm (serial number HDW1855). There were 14 live rounds in magazine 1 and 1 live round chambered for a total of 15 rounds. The capacity of magazine 1 is 17 rounds. Fully loaded, Officer Kusumos firearm holds 18 rounds. The number of rounds remaining in the firearm is consistent with the evidence showing she fired at Garibay a total of three times. No rounds were missing from Officer Kusumos remaining two magazines. WITNESS STATEMENTS Gilbert Garibays grandson, told MPD Officer Chavez that Gilbert left their house around 0100 hours. went to look for Garibay around 0130 hours, because he had not come home. found the officers on M Street and told Officer Chavez that his grandfather was diabetic. Officer Chavez did not tell that his grandfather was shot by officers. Gilbert Garibays daughter, told Detective Rocha that her father never gets up to take a walk. explained that her father took blood thinners, had a stint, and had a balloon in his heart Page 16 from a prior heart attack. did state that she lived in a separate house from her parents. Gilberts wife, was also present while spoke to Detective Rocha. stated Gilbert had woken up two nights prior and stated, somebody was coming to get him. said Gilbert also said somebody in the family was going to get him and everybody knew about it. did not know what Gilbert was talking about. Both and explained that Gilbert lived in fear. said since Gilberts change in behavior he felt he needed to have a weapon. told Detective Rocha that Gilbert had a lot of knives. On the night of this incident, Gilbert gave all his money and debit card before they went to bed together. Detective Rocha asked if Gilbert had ever given her his money and debit card before and said, No. None of the family members interviewed said Gilbert had a history of mental health problems. AUTOPSY On October 27, 2023, Forensic Pathologist Sam Andrews with NAAG Forensic PC performed an autopsy on Gilbert Garibay at the Merced County Sheriffs Office Coroners Facilility. Dr. Andrews determined the cause of the death to be gunshot wounds. In addition, the other significant contributory cause(s) of death were atherosclerotic and hypertensive cardiovascular disease. Garibay had gunshot wounds to his neck, two to the right side of this chest, right shoulder, right thigh, lower right leg, lower left leg, and a graze gunshot wound to the right side of his face. The gunshot wound to Garibays neck caused major injuries to the thyroid gland, trachea, esophagus, spinal cord, thoracic vertebrae, and left lung. The gunshot wounds to Garibays upper right chest caused injuries to his right lung, right clavicle, right ribs, and right arm. The gunshot wounds to Garibays legs were soft tissue injuries only. Dr. Andrewss incidental findings revealed enlargement of the heart; moderate hardening and narrowing in the stented region of the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart muscle, a single gallstone, and enlargement and nodularity of the prostate gland. TOXICOLOGY Toxicology tests revealed Garibays blood was negative for ethanol and drugs. CONTACT WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT No prior law enforcement contacts were located. Furthermore, there was no exact match found when running a criminal history on Gilbert Garibay. INVESTIGATOR NELSONS TRAINING AND EXPERENCE WITH EDGED WEAPONS Throughout my 25 years as a law enforcement officer, I have received ongoing firearm and defensive tactic training. It has been consistently taught to me that edged weapon attacks are highly fatal. In addition, a subject with an edged weapon has the ability to close the distance of 21 feet before I can identify the threat, make a decision and react properly with deadly force. Page 17 APPLICABLE LAW California Penal Code, Section 196 details the circumstances when a public officers intentional killing of another is justified. CALCRIM 507, a jury instruction, uses plain language to describe the elements of Penal Code, Section 196, stating: . . . if he killed someone while acting as a public officer. . . such a killing is justified, and therefore not unlawful, if: 1. The person who killed another was a public officer; 2. The killing was committed while overcoming actual resistance to some legal process or while performing any other legal duty; 3. The killing was necessary to accomplish one of those lawful purposes; AND 4. The public officer had probable cause to believe that the decedent posed a threat of death or great bodily injury, either to the public officer or to others or that the decedent had committed (insert applicable crime here) and that crime threatened the public officer or others with death or great bodily injury. A person has probable cause to believe that someone poses a threat of death or great bodily injury when facts known to the person would persuade someone of reasonable caution that the other person is going to cause death or great bodily injury to another. Great bodily injury means significant or substantial physical injury. It is an injury that is greater than minor or moderate harm. The People have the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the killing was not justified. If the People have not met this burden, a jury must find the public officer not guilty of murder or manslaughter. (As was intended by the authors, the language above was modified or removed to correspond to the circumstances of this case. Changes are shown in brackets. The full text of CALCRIM 507 is attached in the appendix.) A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a person has committed a public offense or is a danger to others may use reasonable force to detain or arrest the person, to prevent the persons escape, or to overcome the persons resistance. (California Penal Code, Section 835a; CALCRIM 2670.) An officer who detains or arrests a person does not need to retreat or stop his or her efforts if the person resists or threatens resistance. Moreover, using reasonable force does not make the officer an aggressor or cause him or her to lose the right to self-defense. (California Penal Code, Section 835a.) The person being detained or arrested has a duty to permit himself or herself to be detained, and the person must refrain from using force or any weapon to resist arrest. (People v. Allen (1980) 109 Cal.App.3d 981, 985; California Penal Code, Section 834a; CALCRIM 2670, 2671, 2672.) A peace officer may use deadly force under circumstances where it is reasonably necessary for self- defense or defense of another. (California Penal Code, Sections, 196 and 197.) California law permits the use of deadly force if the person actually and reasonable believed he/she or another was in imminent danger of death or great bodily injury. It is the reasonable appearance of danger to the officer and his/her Page 18 honest belief in that danger which is controlling. If an officer actually believes that deadly force is necessary and that belief is reasonable under the circumstances, the officers actions are lawful even if it is later determined that the danger did not actually exist. (CALCRIM 505, 507; People v. Toledo (1948) 85 Cal.App.2d 577; People v. Jackson (1965) 233 Cal.App.2d 639.) Further, the officer need not prove that he/she had the right to use deadly force. Rather, it is the prosecution which must prove that the officer did not have that right.

. . 0 tay on wo California consti CITY ATTORNEYS OFFICE 831-646-3915 (TEL) May 23, 2024 Via E-Mail Katey Rusch MuckRock News 163621-98721642requests.muckrock.com Dear Ms. Rusch, The City of Monterey previously produced to your organization all records required to be released pursuant to Penal Code section 832.7 for incidents occurring since 2014. Specifically, the dates of the incidents for which records were previously produced were October 6, 2015, December 17, 2017, July 11, 2020, and August 15, 2020. There is one new incident since the Citys response last year. The City of Monterey Police Department (MPD) responded to a mutual aid request from the City of Seaside. This is documented in MPD Case No. YG2302302. understand that this case involved a suspect who sustained injuries to his face caused by a California Highway Patrol dog. With respect to the substance of your request, Government Code section 7923.600 generally does not require ...the disclosure of records of complaints to, or investigations conducted by, or records of intelligence information or security procedures of ... any state or local police agency.J Under no circumstance does Government Code section 7923.600 require the disclosure of that portion of those investigative files that reflects the analysis or conclusions of the investigating officer. (Gov. Code, 7923.605, subd. (b).) Accordingly, the full the police report, including its analysis and the conclusions reflected therein, is exempt from disclosure pursuant to the aforementioned Code sections. Subject to those restrictions, Government Code sections 7923.610 and 7923.615 contain enumerated exceptions allowing limited disclosure of specific, non-private information relating to arrests and to complaints or requests for assistance.
